    function loadScriptDynamically(scriptUrl) {
        var gads = document.createElement('script'),
            node = document.getElementsByTagName('script') [0];
        gads.async = true;
        gads.src = scriptUrl;
        node.parentNode.insertBefore(gads, node);

<script nonce="cbfbdebc1365489c85901293a87e6adc">
    googletag.cmd.push(function () {
        var sizes = {
            leaderboard: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([320, 100], [[300, 50], [320, 50]])
                .addSize([740, 100], [728, 90])
                .addSize([0, 0], 'fluid')
                .build(),
            mobileleaderboard: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([300, 100], [300, 50])
                .addSize([320, 100], [320, 50])
                .build(),
            mobilefooter: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([0, 0], [300, 50])
                .addSize([0, 0], [320, 50])
                .build(),
            rail: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([0, 0], [300, 250])
                .build(),
            interstitial: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([0, 0], [640, 480])
                .build()
        };

        gptPage = window.digitalData && digitalData.page && digitalData.page.page ? digitalData.page.page : "blank";
        gptSubPage = window.digitalData && digitalData.page && digitalData.page.subPage ? digitalData.page.subPage : "blank";

        function gptClean(gptText) {
            if (typeof (gptText) == "string") {
                gptText = gptText.replace(/\&/g, '%26');
                return gptText.replace(/\^|\*|#|\$|\"|\'|\=|\,|\!|\+|\~|\;|\(|\)|\<|\>|\[|\]|\?|\%|\:|\@|\;|\&|\||\{|\}|\\|/g, '');
            }
            return "blank";
        }

        googletag.pubads()
            .setTargeting('property', 'value-of-property')    // Change and duplicate this line for as many additional keywords to send
            .setTargeting('doi', gptClean('10.1002/cnl2.171')) // Publication DOI
            .setTargeting('pbPage', gptClean(gptPage))
            .setTargeting('pbSubPage', gptClean(gptSubPage))
            .setTargeting('urlpath', gptClean(document.location.pathname));

        googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-leaderboard')
            .defineSizeMapping(sizes.leaderboard)
            .addService(googletag.pubads())
            .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        // googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-mobileleaderboard')
        //     .defineSizeMapping(sizes.mobileleaderboard)
        //     .addService(googletag.pubads())
        //     .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-mobileleaderboard')
        //     .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        // googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-mobilefooter')
        //     .defineSizeMapping(sizes.mobilefooter)
        //     .addService(googletag.pubads())
        //     .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-mobilefooter')
        //     .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-rail-1')
            .defineSizeMapping(sizes.rail)
            .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-rail-1')
            .addService(googletag.pubads())
            .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-rail-2')
            .defineSizeMapping(sizes.rail)
            .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-rail-2')
            .addService(googletag.pubads())
            .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        // googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-video')
        //     .defineSizeMapping(sizes.interstitial)
        //     .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-video')
        //     .addService(googletag.pubads())
        //     .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);


        // googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();


        if(isProgrammaticAdsEnabled) {
            // PERICLES-17135
            googletag.pubads().disableInitialLoad();
        }

        googletag.enableServices();
    });

    if(isProgrammaticAdsEnabled) {
        googletag.cmd.push(function () {
            apstag.fetchBids({timeout: 2000}, function (bids) {
                apstag.setDisplayBids();
                googletag.pubads().refresh();
            });
        });
    }
</script>







    <!-- Get whether TNSI is in live or test mode -->
    
    <!-- Get the configured TNSI Javascript version number -->
    
    <!-- Get the configured TNSI MerchantID -->
    
    <!-- Add "TEST" to beginning of merchant ID when running in test mode -->
    

    
<!-- loading Javascript for using the persistence Service -->
    <script src="/templates/jsp/pb2/js/plugin/thiss-ds.js" nonce="cbfbdebc1365489c85901293a87e6adc"></script>

    <script type="text/javascript" nonce="cbfbdebc1365489c85901293a87e6adc">

        function getParameter(parameterName) {
            let result = null,
                tmp = [];
            location.search
                .substr(1)
                .split("&")
                .forEach(function (item) {
                    tmp = item.split("=");
                    if (tmp[0] === parameterName) result = tmp[1];
                });
            return result;
        }

        var SeamlessAccessService = {
            spUrl: "/action/ssostart",
            returnURL: window.location.href,
            my_context: 'seamlessaccess.org',
            queryParamsDelimiter: encodeURIComponent('?'),

            getWAYFLessUrl: function (entityId) {
                let redirectURL = getParameter('redirectUri');
                if(redirectURL == null){
                    redirectURL = encodeURIComponent(this.returnURL);
                }
                if(redirectURL.indexOf('saml_referrer') < 0){
                    redirectURL += encodeURIComponent(((redirectURL.indexOf(this.queryParamsDelimiter) !== -1) ? '&' : '?') + 'saml_referrer');
                }
                return this.spUrl + "?idp=" + encodeURIComponent(entityId)
                    + "&redirectUri=" + redirectURL;
            },
            retrieveEntity: function () {
                var self = this;
                var ps = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    ps.entities(self.my_context)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            // get the results
                            var results = res.data;
                            return resolve(results);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            reject('retrieve entity error: ' + err);
                        });
                });
            },
            updateEntity: function (entitydata) {
                var self = this;
                var ps = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                var jsonObj = {};
                try {
                    //try to parse it, if it is a json string
                    jsonObj = JSON.parse(entitydata.val());
                } catch (e) {
                    jsonObj = entitydata;
                }
                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    ps.update(self.my_context, jsonObj)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            // Process the results
                            var ssoInstitutions = res.data;
                            return resolve(ssoInstitutions);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            console.log('failed to update the local storage duo to: ' + err);
                            reject(err);
                        });
                })
            },
            removeEntity: function (entityId) {
                var self = this;
                var persistService = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                return new Promise(function (resolve) {
                    persistService.remove(self.my_context, entityId)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            return resolve(res);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            console.log('failed to remove from local storage duo to: ' + err);
                        });
                })
            },
            getAccessibleEntityStatus: function (doi, entityId, entityTitle) {
                return new Promise(function (resolve) {
                    $.ajax({
                        type: 'POST',
                        url: '/action/seamlessAccess',
                        accept: {
                            text: "application/json"
                        },
                        data: {doi: doi, entityid: entityId, entityTitle: entityTitle, eventGroupKey: '03ad851d-ef53-4042-ac1e-966e963d915e'}

                    }).done(function (status) {
                        return resolve(status);
                    });
                });
            },
            getEntitiesWithAllInfo: function (doi) {
                let self = this,
                    arrayOfPromises = [];
                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    self.retrieveEntity().then(function (res) {
                        let allSsoInstitutions = res;
                        for (let i in allSsoInstitutions) {
                            let ssoInstitution = allSsoInstitutions[i];
                            arrayOfPromises.push(new Promise(function (resolve) {
                                self.getAccessibleEntityStatus(doi, ssoInstitution.entity.entityID, ssoInstitution.entity.title)
                                    .then(function (entityStatus) {
                                        resolve({
                                            entityID: ssoInstitution.entity.entityID,
                                            entityTitle: ssoInstitution.entity.title,
                                            entityStatusObj: entityStatus,
                                            entitySsoUrl: self.getWAYFLessUrl(ssoInstitution.entity.entityID)
                                        });
                                    }, function (err) {
                                        console.log('failed to get the entity status: ' + err);
                                    });
                            }));
                        }
                        Promise.all(arrayOfPromises)
                            .then(function (finalResponse) {
                                resolve(finalResponse);
                            });

                    }).catch(function (err) {
                        reject(err);
                    })
                });
            }
        };

        window.addEventListener('load', function () {
            document.querySelectorAll(".sso-institution").forEach(function (institution) {
                var entityId = institution.getAttribute('data-entityid');
                var entityName = institution.getAttribute('data-name');
                var entitydata = {
                    entityID: entityId,
                    title: entityName
                };
                institution.addEventListener("click", function (e) {
                    e.preventDefault();
                    var self = this;
                    SeamlessAccessService.updateEntity(entitydata).then(function (res) {
                        console.log(res);
                        window.location.href = self.href;
                    }).catch(function (err){
                        window.location.href = self.href;
                    });
                });
            });
        });

    </script>
    <script nonce="cbfbdebc1365489c85901293a87e6adc">
            (function() {
                function isBrowserChrome() {
                    return /Chrome/.test(navigator.userAgent) && /Google Inc/.test(navigator.vendor);
                }

                if (isBrowserChrome()) {
                    const originTrialToken = 'Air1DGksXVMUq7OQa9ACAT2gaCv+U6CpLQXfhVX2S0f3mukgWCvoj650vSgN0tj0lfkKd65dGzGX3Hgla76yIAAAAACJeyJvcmlnaW4iOiJodHRwczovL29ubGluZWxpYnJhcnkud2lsZXkuY29tOjQ0MyIsImZlYXR1cmUiOiJEaXNhYmxlVGhpcmRQYXJ0eVN0b3JhZ2VQYXJ0aXRpb25pbmcyIiwiZXhwaXJ5IjoxNzQyMzQyMzk5LCJpc1N1YmRvbWFpbiI6dHJ1ZX0=';
                    const originTrialMetaTag = document.createElement('meta');
                    originTrialMetaTag.httpEquiv = 'origin-trial';
                    originTrialMetaTag.content = originTrialToken;
                    document.head.append(originTrialMetaTag);
                }
            })();
        </script>
    <script type="text/javascript" nonce="cbfbdebc1365489c85901293a87e6adc">
        (function() {
            function riskifiedBeaconLoad() {
                var store_domain = 'https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com';
                var session_id = '3F60505915A4D25DE95282EA63E47484';
                var url = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https://' : 'http://')
                    + "beacon.riskified.com?shop=" + store_domain + "&sid=" + session_id;
                var s = document.createElement('script');
                s.type = 'text/javascript';
                s.async = true;
                s.src = url;
                var x = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
                x.parentNode.insertBefore(s, x);
            }
            if (window.attachEvent)
                window.attachEvent('onload', riskifiedBeaconLoad)
            else
                window.addEventListener('load', riskifiedBeaconLoad, false);
        })();
    </script>

        <div class="container"><div class="row"><div class="contents col-sm-12 col-md-12">









    
    
        <div data-widget-def="UX3InstitutionBanner" data-widget-id="0a735273-4141-44d8-801a-2b89143bed55" class="institution-wrapper-mobile hidden-lg padded-content">

   <h1 class="citation__title" lang="en">High-abundance and low-cost anodes for sodium-ion batteries</h1>
   <div class="pb-dropzone" data-pb-dropzone="publicaitonContent-versions"><!-- Empty dropzone --></div>
   <div class="loa comma visible-xs mobile-authors loa-authors-trunc">

               <p>Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials, Faculty of Engineering and Information Sciences, University of Wollongong, North Wollongong, New South Wales, Australia</p>

               <p>Email: <a class="corr-email" title="Link to email address" href="mailto:jiazhao@uow.edu.au"><span>jiazhao@uow.edu.au</span></a></p>
               <p>Jun Wang, Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution and Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), Shandong University, Jinan 250061, China.</p>
               <p>Email: <a class="corr-email" title="Link to email address" href="mailto:jw707@sdu.edu.cn"><span>jw707@sdu.edu.cn</span></a></p><a class="moreInfoLink" href="/authored-by/Wang/Jiazhao">Search for more papers by this author</a></div></span><span class="accordion-tabbed__tab-mobile  accordion__closed"><a href="/authored-by/Wang/Jun" class="author-name accordion-tabbed__control" data-id="am11" data-db-target-for="am11" aria-controls="am11" aria-haspopup="true" id="am11_Ctrl" role="button"><span>Jun Wang<i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-mail_outline"></i></span><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-section_arrow_d"></i></a><span class="comma-separator">,&nbsp;</span><div class="author-info accordion-tabbed__content" data-db-target-of="am11" aria-labelledby="am11_Ctrl" role="region" id="am11">
               <p class="author-type mb-1">Corresponding Author</p>
               <p class="author-name">Jun Wang</p>
               <ul class="rlist sm-account">
                  <li class="sm-account__item"><a class="sm-account__link" title="Link to email address" href="mailto:jw707@sdu.edu.cn"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-ic_mail_solid"></i><span>jw707@sdu.edu.cn</span></a></li>
               </ul>
               <p>Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution and Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), Shandong University, Jinan, China</p>

   <div class="abstract-group ">
      <section class="article-section article-section__abstract" lang="en" data-lang="en" lang-name="English" id="section-1-en">
         <h2 id="d33609759" class="article-section__header section__title main abstractlang_en main">Abstract</h2>
         <div class="article-section__content en main">
            
            <p>Nowadays, sodium-ion batteries are considered the most promising large-scale energy storage systems (EESs) due to the low cost and wide distribution of sodium sources as well as the similar working principle to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). Therefore, screening suitable materials with high abundance, low cost, and excellent reliability and modified with different strategies based on them is the key point for the development of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). In addition, the ideal anodes with high abundance, and low cost elements also greatly influence the cost of SIB systems, determining the large-scale application. Herein, recent advances in carbon, iron, manganese, and phosphorus-based anodes of various types, such as hard carbon, iron oxides, manganese oxides, and red phosphorus, are highlighted. The various sodium storage mechanisms and structure-function properties for these four types of materials are summarized and analyzed in detail. Considering the commercial profits that the EESs can bring and their suitability for mass electrode manufacturing, the participation of high-abundance and low-cost elements such as Fe, Mn, C, and P is convincing and encouraging.</p></div>
      </section>
   </div>
   <div class="pb-dropzone" data-pb-dropzone="below-abstract-group"><!-- Empty dropzone --></div>
   
   <section class="article-section article-section__full">
      <section class="article-section__content" id="cnl2171-sec-0010">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="cnl2171-sec-0010-title">1 INTRODUCTION</h2>
         
         <p>Since the 21st century, social problems many countries faced mainly concentrated on the excessive consumption of fossil fuels and the exacerbation of environmental pollution, and it is thus urgent to meet the goal of carbon neutrality or net-zero carbon emission.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0001" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0001_R_d33609751e506" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 1 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">1</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0003" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0003_R_d33609751e506" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 3 - Energy Environ. Sci.">3</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Various countries and organizations have initiated to accelerate the exploitation of new renewable clean energy sources (such as solar and wind energy) to reduce the emission of pollutants, but most of these systems are severely limited by intermittent and random outputs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0004" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0004_R_d33609751e511" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 4 - Chem. Rev.">4</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0005" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0005_R_d33609751e511" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 5 - Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.">5</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Energy storage devices are considered to be an effective instrument to solve this issue, and they exhibit the characteristics of large-scale, sustainable, and eco-friendly. In the early 1970s, it was reported that lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) were used as primary batteries.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0006" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0006_R_d33609751e516" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 6 - Science">6</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0008" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0008_R_d33609751e516" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 8 - Rare Met.">8</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Since Sony and Asahi Chemical successfully commercialized rechargeable LIBs with graphite as anode materials in 1990, it has been extensively employed as the common power source in the market of portable electronics, which announced the arrival of a new “LIB Era.”<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0009" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0009_R_d33609751e522" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 9 - Energy Environ. Sci.">9</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0011" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0011_R_d33609751e522" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 11 - Energy Environ. Sci.">11</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Although LIBs have achieved great effort in the energy storage field, there are fatal issues such as the low abundance and uneven distribution of lithium sources severely limiting their further development. Thus, the attention of researchers has currently shifted to sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), due to the low cost and wide distribution of sodium sources with their similar chemical and physical properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0012" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0012_R_d33609751e527" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 12 - Adv. Energy Mater.">12</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0013" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0013_R_d33609751e527" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 13 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">13</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, the price of aluminum is lower than that of copper, which can be employed as the current collector both at the anode and cathode in SIBs, since it does not form an alloy with sodium.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0014" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0014_R_d33609751e533" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 14 - Adv. Mater.">14</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0015" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0015_R_d33609751e533" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 15 - InfoMat">15</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Compared to Li-ion, which has a radius of 0.76 Å, the Na-ion shows a larger radius of 1.2 Å and exhibits a higher reduction potential of 0.3 V, resulting in problems in finding suitable host materials for them with sluggish kinetics to inevitably present lower specific capacities, inferior rate, and poor cycling performance. Besides, Na probably poses a safety threat because of the relatively low melting point, when used as anodes under ambient temperature.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0016" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0016_R_d33609751e540" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 16 - Energy Environ. Sci.">16</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0018" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0018_R_d33609751e540" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 18 - Rare Met.">18</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, considerable efforts have been made to develop SIB-related techniques and make them marketable, especially in terms of anode materials playing a vital role in affecting battery performance.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0019" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0019_R_d33609751e545" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 19 - Natl. Sci. Rev.">19</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> To date, there are numerous materials reported as anode materials carbon-based (such as hard carbon,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0020" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0020_R_d33609751e550" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 20 - Adv. Mater.">20</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0022" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0022_R_d33609751e550" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 22 - Adv. Mater.">22</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> graphite,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0023_R_d33609751e556" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Small">23</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0024" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0024_R_d33609751e556" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 24 - Nat. Commun.">24</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> nanocarbon<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0025" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0025_R_d33609751e561" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 25 - Small">25</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0026" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0026_R_d33609751e561" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 26 - Mater. Today Nano">26</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), transition metal oxide, and sulfide (such as TiO<sub>2</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0027" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0027_R_d33609751e569" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 27 - Adv. Energy Mater.">27</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0028_R_d33609751e569" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Chem. Commun.">28</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0029" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0029_R_d33609751e578" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">29</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0031" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0031_R_d33609751e578" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 31 - J. Alloys Compd.">31</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0032" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0032_R_d33609751e588" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 32 - J. Alloys Compd.">32</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0034" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0034_R_d33609751e588" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 34 - Energy Environ. Mater.">34</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> MnO<sub>2</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0035" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0035_R_d33609751e596" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 35 - RSC Adv.">35</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0036" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0036_R_d33609751e596" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 36 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">36</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Mn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0037" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0037_R_d33609751e605" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 37 - Sci. Rep.">37</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0038" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0038_R_d33609751e605" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 38 - Ceram. Int.">38</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> FeS<sub>2</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0039" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0039_R_d33609751e613" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 39 - Nano-Micro Lett.">39</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0040_R_d33609751e613" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - J. Mater. Chem. A">40</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> MnS,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0041" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0041_R_d33609751e618" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 41 - Mater. Lett.">41</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0042" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0042_R_d33609751e618" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 42 - Chem. Eng. J.">42</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> MoS<sub>2</sub>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0043_R_d33609751e626" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">43</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0045" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0045_R_d33609751e626" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 45 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">45</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), phosphorus-based (such as black phosphorus,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0046" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0046_R_d33609751e631" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 46 - ACS Nano">46</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0047" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0047_R_d33609751e631" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 47 - J. Energy Storage">47</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> red phosphorus<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0048" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0048_R_d33609751e636" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 48 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">48</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0049" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0049_R_d33609751e636" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 49 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">49</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), and organic-based<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0050" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0050_R_d33609751e642" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 50 - Small">50</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0051" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0051_R_d33609751e642" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 51 - Energy Environ. Sci.">51</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> materials, and so forth. Given the practical commercialization of LIBs, low-cost and earth-rich elements should be contained in the advanced anodes. Among the materials above, carbon-based, iron/manganese oxides/sulfides, and phosphorus-based materials have attracted a great many research interest owing to their natural abundance and economics, as shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0001">1a,b</a>, which are demonstrated to be effective for sodium storage. Based on these, the anode manufactory expenditures of SIBs would be surely reduced, and the performance is also expected to be enhanced. However, most of these materials typically face common issues including huge volume expansion of the host materials, due to the continuous self-pulverization of the anode materials<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0052" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0052_R_d33609751e650" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 52 - Chem. Eur. J.">52</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0053" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0053_R_d33609751e650" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 53 - Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.">53</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> with sluggish reaction kinetics.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0017" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0017_R_d33609751e656" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 17 - Chem. Soc. Rev.">17</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0054" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0054_R_d33609751e656" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 54 - Energy Environ. Sci.">54</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Besides, some anode materials such as red phosphorus suffer from low electrical conductivity, triggering undesirable low practical specific capacity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0048" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0048_R_d33609751e661" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 48 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">48</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0055" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0055_R_d33609751e661" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 55 - J. Alloys Compd.">55</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> To solve these challenges, tremendous measures have been taken mainly in three ways, including microstructure modulation, composition construction, and active site increase.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0001"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/143bdeb7-c9e1-4231-a94d-16e3549cc697/cnl2171-fig-0001-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/143bdeb7-c9e1-4231-a94d-16e3549cc697/cnl2171-fig-0001-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/a9f60542-74a8-4273-9ad5-2814e9ad5d32/cnl2171-fig-0001-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/143bdeb7-c9e1-4231-a94d-16e3549cc697/cnl2171-fig-0001-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 1<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0001&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Element abundances in the Earth's crust and (b) prices. The data were collected from the Shanghai metals market on May 31, 2024.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         
         <p>There are many review papers on anode materials for SIBs, focusing on the energy storage mechanisms, high energy density, high specific capacity, and long cycle life, have been published, proposing many critical challenges and opportunities of anodes for SIBs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0056" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0056_R_d33609751e689" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 56 - ACS Cent. Sci.">56</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0060" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0060_R_d33609751e689" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 60 - Energy Storage Mater.">60</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Nevertheless, to the best of our knowledge, no dedicated review papers focus on high-performance anode materials containing earth-abundance, low-cost, and nontoxic elements, which is the key point for the commercial of SIBs. In addition, when considering the commercial profits that the EESs can bring and their suitability for mass electrode manufacturing, the participation of high-abundance and low-cost elements such as Fe, Mn, C, and P is convincing and encouraging. Therefore, in this review, the recent progress on high abundance and low-cost anodes containing carbon-based materials, phosphorus-based materials, iron-based materials, and manganese-based materials were summarized for advanced low-cost SIB systems. The importance of developing low-cost and high-abundance anodes was presented from a practical perspective. Moreover, the sodium storage principles of diverse materials were specified, and the characteristics of the three main mechanisms were proposed. Furthermore, these four types of materials with an account of their existing merits and shortcomings were discussed, as depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0002">2</a>. All in all, based on the information above, this review would contribute to rationalizing the design of advanced anode materials for SIBs.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0002"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/0a5b56e9-f00c-4ad4-aa83-05801ee31a30/cnl2171-fig-0002-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/0a5b56e9-f00c-4ad4-aa83-05801ee31a30/cnl2171-fig-0002-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/4d17470f-94f9-48ea-8035-d0abcb8119da/cnl2171-fig-0002-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/0a5b56e9-f00c-4ad4-aa83-05801ee31a30/cnl2171-fig-0002-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 2<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0002&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Overview of the classification of high abundance and low-cost materials, main mechanisms, and their enhancement strategies for future application.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="cnl2171-sec-0020">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="cnl2171-sec-0020-title">2 ADVANTAGES OF DEVELOPING HIGH-ABUNDANCE AND LOW-COST ANODE</h2>
         
         <p>Typically, SIBs consist of four key components, including cathode, anode, electrolyte, and separator, which are placed in the cell assembling process appropriately. It is well known that the electrode materials account for the largest part of the total battery cost (≥50%).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0061" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0061_R_d33609751e727" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 61 - Renewable Sustainable Energy Rev.">61</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0062" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0062_R_d33609751e727" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 62 - Energy Environ. Sci.">62</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Among all the elements that are available as anode materials in SIBs, research on C, Fe, Mn, and P-based materials with the advantages of both large reserves and low prices is becoming a hot topic, and the number of related papers previously published were summarized between 2021 and May 2024, as depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0003">3a</a> with the proportion of the various corresponding materials in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0003">3b–e</a>. Though similar reaction mechanisms with those of LIBs were offered (intercalation/de-intercalation, conversion reaction, and alloying/de-alloying reactions),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0063" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0063_R_d33609751e738" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 63 - Energy Environ. Sci.">63</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0064" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0064_R_d33609751e738" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 64 - Sustainable Energy Fuels">64</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> it is still a challenge to employ appreciate anode materials for SIBs due to the natural characteristics including larger ions radius, high operational potentials, anode volume expansion, and pulverization during cycling.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0024" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0024_R_d33609751e744" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 24 - Nat. Commun.">24</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0061" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0061_R_d33609751e744" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 61 - Renewable Sustainable Energy Rev.">61</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0065" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0065_R_d33609751e744" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 65 - J. Mater. Chem. A">65</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, regarding the above discussion on commercial profitability as well as their unique applicability in the field of energy storage, exploiting low-cost and high-abundance materials as advanced anode materials for SIBs is critical and inspiring.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0003"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/7259582f-2af0-4926-9764-a11ee7e4b7b8/cnl2171-fig-0003-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/7259582f-2af0-4926-9764-a11ee7e4b7b8/cnl2171-fig-0003-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/4dc1f606-8601-4a23-9800-d0d5a9704fdc/cnl2171-fig-0003-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/7259582f-2af0-4926-9764-a11ee7e4b7b8/cnl2171-fig-0003-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 3<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0003&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Number of publications on four classification materials according to the data from the Web of Science. Ratios of various types of (b) carbon-based, (c) P-based (d) Fe-based, and (e) Mn-based anodes in the published research articles (as of May 2024).</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="cnl2171-sec-0030">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="cnl2171-sec-0030-title">3 EMERGING HIGH-ABUNDANCE LOW-COST ANODE MATERIALS</h2>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0040">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="cnl2171-sec-0040-title">3.1 Carbonaceous materials</h3>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0050">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0050-title">3.1.1 Hard carbon materials (HC)</h4>
               
               <p>HC have been widely investigated and used as anode materials for SIBs, which are most likely to be commercialized due to their low cost, low charge/discharge overpotentials, and excellent cycling stability.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0066" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0066_R_d33609751e788" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 66 - eScience">66</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In general, HC materials are mainly derived from the carbonization of biomass<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0067" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0067_R_d33609751e793" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 67 - Energy Storage Mater.">67</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0071" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0071_R_d33609751e793" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 71 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">71</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or synthetic polymer,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0072" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0072_R_d33609751e798" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 72 - Small Methods">72</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0074" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0074_R_d33609751e798" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 74 - Small">74</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and the degree of graphitization, pore size, and specific surface area are subjected to the pyrolysis temperature, which further leads to highly disordered structure and larger interlayer distance.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0075_R_d33609751e804" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In 2017, Qiu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0076" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0076_R_d33609751e809" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 76 - Adv. Energy Mater.">76</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used the in-situ and ex-situ detection techniques to probe the structural changes of the HC anode, which demonstrated that an “adsorption-intercalation” process is dominant during sodium storage processes, as shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0004">4a</a>. Specifically, during discharging-charging, Na ions first adsorbed on the active sites on HC surfaces, leading to a sloping voltage profile due to a wide distribution of adsorption energies, and then Na ions were intercalated into graphene layers with suitable spacing to form NaC<sub>x</sub> compounds, resulting in a flat voltage plateau similar to that of the Li-graphite counterpart.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0076" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0076_R_d33609751e820" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 76 - Adv. Energy Mater.">76</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0004"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/4d7f4a60-4418-4dad-ba6e-38b61ccdd6f7/cnl2171-fig-0004-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/4d7f4a60-4418-4dad-ba6e-38b61ccdd6f7/cnl2171-fig-0004-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/5871ab07-c8b8-427f-9eb8-8217b9b31c28/cnl2171-fig-0004-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/4d7f4a60-4418-4dad-ba6e-38b61ccdd6f7/cnl2171-fig-0004-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 4<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0004&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Schematic illustration of the route to fabricate Hx-1100 via prereduction and post-high-temperature carbonization. (b) Sodiation mechanism of H300-1100. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2022, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0067" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0067_R_d33609751e844" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 67 - Energy Storage Mater.">67</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (c) Illustration of preparation procedure of 3DPCS-800-N. (d) Calculated models with electron density difference and density functional theory (DFT) models for the diffusion path of sodium ions. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2021, Wiley.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0072" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0072_R_d33609751e849" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 72 - Small Methods">72</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (e) Schematic diagram of the oxidation and reduction processes. (f) Adsorption models and adsorption energy of one sodium over the pristine carbon surface and near carboxyl and hydroxyl groups. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2022, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0077" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0077_R_d33609751e854" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 77 - Chem. Eng. J.">77</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (g) Schematic of the atomic layer deposition (ALD) process for depositing Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> on the surface of the HC anode. (h) Schematic of the influence of ALD-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> coating on HC. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0073" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0073_R_d33609751e869" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 73 - Nano Energy">73</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               
               <p>Even though HC anodes represent unique advantages, there are still barriers getting in the way of their application, particularly relatively insufficient initial Columbic efficiency (ICE).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0078" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0078_R_d33609751e877" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 78 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">78</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0081" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0081_R_d33609751e877" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 81 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">81</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> A large number of researchers have made great efforts to solve the above-mentioned problems. Tuning carbonization temperature is widely recognized as regulating the degree of graphitization for HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0022" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0022_R_d33609751e882" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 22 - Adv. Mater.">22</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Song et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0067" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0067_R_d33609751e887" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 67 - Energy Storage Mater.">67</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> selected the esterified starch as a model precursor and quantitatively regulated its oxygen content by low-temperature hydrogen reduction (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0004">4a</a>), indicating that decreasing the oxygen content of the precursor with guaranteeing the stability of the crosslinking structure could promote the closure of open pores and the orientated alignment of carbon layers at relatively low carbonization temperature (1100°C). Also, a sodiation mechanism was proposed via the advanced characteristic analysis, such as in-situ Raman and Galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0004">4b</a>. Generally, the processes can be regarded as three stages, in which Na ions are first adsorbed on defect sites, which are abundant in the prepared HC. Afterward, it was inserted into the pseudo-graphite layers, and Na ions were eventually filled in closed pores until the intercalation sites were saturated. The accessibility of closed pores was a key factor in achieving high plateau capacity. Therefore, the optimized HC anode exhibited a high specific capacity of 369.8 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> with an ICE of 82.5% at 20 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Hou et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0082" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0082_R_d33609751e906" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 82 - Chem. Pap.">82</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared HC anode via different pyrolysis carbonization routes and likewise suggested that the micro-structure and the ICE of HC were largely affected by the carbonization temperature. Zhao et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0083" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0083_R_d33609751e911" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 83 - Adv. Energy Mater.">83</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> employed a graphite-promoted low-temperature method at 1300°C to fabricate the HC materials with graphite crystals, and the obtained materials displayed a high-level ordered structure, large domain size, and low defects, leading to a satisfying ICE of 91%. Su et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0084" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0084_R_d33609751e916" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 84 - Rare Met.">84</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> employed pre-oxidation treatment to limit excessive graphitization and increase the disorder of HC, optimizing the performance of sodium storage. Furthermore, it was believed that the limited accessibility of sodiation sites greatly restricts their specific capacities.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0074" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0074_R_d33609751e922" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 74 - Small">74</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0085" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0085_R_d33609751e922" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 85 - Adv. Energy Mater.">85</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0086" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0086_R_d33609751e922" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 86 - Chem. Eng. J.">86</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Dolgos's group revealed that an atomistic view of ion binding sites was responsible for “defect” storage mechanisms in HC by combining the experimental results with the model calculation. Gan et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0072" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0072_R_d33609751e927" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 72 - Small Methods">72</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> introduced abundant C-N and C-C radicals into a HC network and constructed a 3D architecture with a hierarchical porous structure to effectively expose active sites (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0004">4c</a>). It was found that the carbon material anode with ultrahigh radicals showed superior electrochemical performance with a high specific capacity of 434 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 20 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Besides, as shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0004">4d</a>, DFT calculations indicate that N-6 as the main radical features substantially higher Na-adsorption and lowest diffusion barriers, affording higher specific capacity and greater rate capability. Wan et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0087" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0087_R_d33609751e945" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 87 - Energy">87</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized N, S dual-doped porous HC material with many active sites as SIB anode, and its specific capacity can reach 801 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> and 402 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 5 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Tang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0077" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0077_R_d33609751e964" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 77 - Chem. Eng. J.">77</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> introduced abundant oxygen-containing functional groups into the commercial HC by a simple oxidation method, remarkably enlarging interlayer distances and providing abundant Na ion absorption sites (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0004">4e</a>). DFT calculations revealed that the oxygen-containing functional groups could regulate the transport and adsorption process of Na ions on the HC surfaces by providing more active sites for sodium storage (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0004">4f</a>). In addition, as we all know, expanding the interlayers of carbon has been extensively applied to enhance the specific capacities and accelerate the reaction kinetics in SIBs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0088" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0088_R_d33609751e975" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 88 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">88</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, superior electrochemical properties were achieved with an improved reversible specific capacity of 341 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> and excellent rate capability at 5000 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Cai et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0089" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0089_R_d33609751e987" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 89 - Small">89</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> constructed a series of porous and robust HCNFs with tunable interlayer spacings, and their abundant short-range graphitic layers and optimized interlayer spacings of 0.37–0.40 nm resulted in a high reversible specific capacity (388 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 30 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>) and good rate performance (167 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 500 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>). Surface coating technology is another favorable strategy to enhance the ICE by reducing surface areas and inhibiting the generation of excessive solid electrolyte interfaces (SEI).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0090" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0090_R_d33609751e1006" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 90 - Nano Energy">90</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0091" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0091_R_d33609751e1006" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 91 - Energy Environ. Sci.">91</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Cao and colleagues<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0073" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0073_R_d33609751e1011" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 73 - Nano Energy">73</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> deposited an ultrathin Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> film on HC by a simple direct atomic layer deposition (ALD) method (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0004">4g</a>), which could effectively suppress the decomposition of electrolyte to obtain an increased ICE of 75% (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0004">4h</a>). He et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0092" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0092_R_d33609751e1027" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 92 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">92</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> applied a soft-carbon coating onto free-standing hard-carbon anodes and proved that high hydrogen-containing molecules in the soft-carbon precursor can reduce the oxygen-containing groups in the hard-carbon precursor, decreasing the consumption of Na ions and achieve a superior ICE of 94.1% and capacity retention of 99% after 100 cycles at 20 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Wu's group synthesized HC coating by a stable homotype amorphous Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> layer to induce the generation of thin and dense SEI film. The resultant HC anode based on this homotype heterojunction exhibited effectively increased ICE of HC from 64.7% to 81.1%.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0093" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0093_R_d33609751e1040" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 93 - Rare Met.">93</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <p>Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0001">1</a> provides a summary of synthesis details and the sodium storage properties of typical above-mentioned hard carbon anodes. It is evident that HC is normally yielded from the pyrolysis of biomass or organic compounds, which is normally defined as “carbonization” with the maintenance of the precursor morphology and release of H<sub>2</sub>O, CO<sub>2</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>, and so forth, and the as-prepared HC thus typically feature high porosity, large specific surface area and a certain degree of graphitization. Specificaly, the pyrolysis of biomass is indeed cost-effective strategy, but the complicated constitutions and impurities in the resultants degrade the consistency and reproducibility. The pyrolysis of polymer hold the ability to obtain unifom material nature, which would be yet more expensive to scale up, and in this regard, biomass-derived polymers (such as cellulose and lignin) are regarded to get a leg up in the way of commercialization. Alvin et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0094" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0094_R_d33609751e1056" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 94 - Chem. Eng. J.">94</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used lignin from oak hardwood with stable structure as carbon soruce incorperating with P atoms to obtain P-doped hard carbon, with a 23% reversible capacity larger than that of undoped hard carbon. Xie et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0095" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0095_R_d33609751e1062" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 95 - Carbon Energy">95</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> achieved high HC initial Coulombic efficiency by tailoring chiral nematic nanocrystalline cellulose, and the optimized microstructures with the removal of amorphous and stacking regions from the chiral nematic phases lead to an increase in the degree of order, achieving an ultrahigh ICE of 90.4% with an excellent capacity of 314 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. All in all, HC is the most mature material and regarded as the optimal available candidate to be commercialized at present. Unfortunately, no discovery has yet been made that takes full advantage of the benefits of HC while overcoming the drawbacks. Currently, there remain some fatal problems that need to be solved. On one hand, as mentioned previously, the inhomogeneity of precursor composition and microstructure could lead to significant differences in the properties and mechanisms of the final products, and it is essential to choose high-quality precursors as typical research targets to optimize the design of microstructure and composition. On the other, we have listed a lot of research in terms of doping and codoping due to the great improvement of performance they bring, but suitable schemes and methods on a way to accurately control doping are normally lacking. It is believed that the HC research could achieve further progress as the anode for SIBs after addressing the above issues.</p>
               
               <div class="article-table-content" id="cnl2171-tbl-0001">

                              <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Reduced chemical treatment HC</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">-</td>

            </section>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0060">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0060-title">3.1.2 Graphite materials</h4>
               
               <p>Graphite, as the most commercial anode for LIBs since the 1990s, has been limited by a very low specific capacity when used in SIBs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0024" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0024_R_d33609751e1728" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 24 - Nat. Commun.">24</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Graphite consists of many layers of graphene weakly bound by van der Waals interaction, resulting in hexagonal ABA or rhombohedral ABC stacking with an interlayer distance of ≈0.335 nm.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0096" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0096_R_d33609751e1733" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 96 - Chem. Soc. Rev.">96</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Guest ions can intercalate into the graphite galleries by forming graphite intercalation compounds (GICs).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0097" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0097_R_d33609751e1738" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 97 - Front. Chem.">97</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> It is believed that, despite graphite showing low cost and chemical/electrochemical stability, Na ions cannot be reversibly inserted into interlayers due to the fact that the interlayer distance of graphite is too small to accommodate the large Na ions.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0098_R_d33609751e1744" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - Nano Lett.">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Instead, Li ions can be intercalated into the interlayers, which greatly facilitates its application in LIBs. Apart from the distance, a previous computational study by Wang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0099" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0099_R_d33609751e1749" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 99 - RSC Adv.">99</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have shown that the formation of sodium-graphite intercalation compound (Na-GIC) is thermodynamically unfavorable. A recent report based on first-principles calculations explored the effect of interlayer distance, also confirming this factor, and the further finding that the thermodynamics of GIC is associated with spacing between graphene layers was made. Na-GIC could be thermodynamically stable when the graphene interlayer distance is greater than about 4.4 Å. The most thermodynamically stable Na-GIC system was found to present an interlayer distance of about 6.0 Å.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0100" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0100_R_d33609751e1755" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 100 - Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.">100</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, a great deal of research has been devoted to alternative anode materials such as expanded graphite (EG), expanded graphite oxide (EGO), or graphite-based compounds with metal atom modulation to overcome the drawbacks of graphite.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0024" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0024_R_d33609751e1760" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 24 - Nat. Commun.">24</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0101" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0101_R_d33609751e1760" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 101 - Energy Environ. Sci.">101</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0102" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0102_R_d33609751e1760" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 102 - Carbon">102</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The nanostructure, capacity at specific current densities, and cycling performance for various graphite anodes are summarized in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0002">2</a>. Additionally, it is proposed that using ether-based electrolytes that accompany co-intercalation reactions can significantly improve the reversible specific capacity and cycling stability of graphite anode.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0103" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0103_R_d33609751e1768" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 103 - Nat. Commun.">103</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0104" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0104_R_d33609751e1768" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 104 - J. Power Sources">104</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <div class="article-table-content" id="cnl2171-tbl-0002">
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  <header class="article-table-caption"><span class="table-caption__label">Table  2.
                    </span>Microstructure and electrochemical performance of various graphite and nanocarbon material anodes for SIBs.</header>
