                           </tbody>
                        </table>
                  </div>
                  
                  <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
               </div>
               <p>One way to enhance the reversible specific capacity of graphite is to expand the interlayer distances, allowing Na ions to intercalate in the EG. EG is a graphite-derived material with an enlarged interlayer distance that retains the long-range ordered layered structure of graphite, yielding a generally large interlayer distance (&gt;0.34 nm). Liu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0105" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0105_R_d33609751e2928" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 105 - Electrochim. Acta">105</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used recycled graphite by acid-treated process (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5a</a>), and the HRTEM image (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5b</a>) exhibited an interlayer distance of 0.345 nm, which corresponds to the (002) plane of graphite and was larger than that of the commercial graphite.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0096" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0096_R_d33609751e2939" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 96 - Chem. Soc. Rev.">96</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0106" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0106_R_d33609751e2939" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 106 - J. Mater. Chem. A">106</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Moreover, an amorphous layer was observed on the surfaces of the graphite, indicating that the acid-treat oxidation of the graphite (AG) decreased the graphitization degree. As a result, the AG anode achieved a reversible specific capacity of 106.8 mAhg<sup>–</sup><sup>1</sup> after 500 cycles at 2000 mAg<sup>–</sup><sup>1</sup> with a high-capacity retention of 90.98% (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5c</a>). As shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5d</a>, Luo et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0107" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0107_R_d33609751e2958" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 107 - Energy Storage Mater.">107</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported a plier-linked graphite network (PGN) with plier-like and conjugated active molecules for sodium-ion battery anode. The interlayer distance of the PGN can be tuned from 1 to 2 nm by different linker active molecules. The plier-linked graphite network (PDA-PGN) anode with 9,9-dihexylfluorene-2,7-diboronic acid (PDA) among variable linkers delivered the highest sodiation/desodiation specific capacities (298/245 mAh g<sup>–</sup><sup>1</sup>), which was about 10 times that of graphite, suggesting that the manipulated interlayer distance (1.02 nm) provided superior ion intercalation. Kim et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0108" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0108_R_d33609751e2966" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 108 - Carbon">108</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> expanded the graphite structure by atomically inserting Group VI cation pillars (W<sup>6+</sup>) between the graphene layers. The W pillars significantly increased the interlayer spacing of the EG materials to ~11 Å, thereby enabling the facile insertion and extraction of Na ions.</p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0005"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/0f3e05a0-1fc3-461b-8e43-d61422e61bea/cnl2171-fig-0005-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/0f3e05a0-1fc3-461b-8e43-d61422e61bea/cnl2171-fig-0005-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/259d1686-0320-417d-be87-100538a51de6/cnl2171-fig-0005-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/0f3e05a0-1fc3-461b-8e43-d61422e61bea/cnl2171-fig-0005-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 5<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0005&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Flowchart of recycling of waste graphite materials. (b) HRTEM images of AG. (c) Rate performances of AG at various current densities. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0105" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0105_R_d33609751e2994" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 105 - Electrochim. Acta">105</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (d) Scheme for synthesizing various covalently pillared PGN and their application as anodes in SIBs. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2021, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0107" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0107_R_d33609751e2999" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 107 - Energy Storage Mater.">107</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (e) Schematic diagram of synthesizing the H-BiS/EGF micro-composite. (f) Long cycle performance at 5 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. (g) Rate capability at current densities from 0.5 to 25 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0109" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0109_R_d33609751e3011" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 109 - Chem. Eng. J.">109</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (h) Schematic model structures of the G2, G1, and graphite peaks in the G-band. (i) Alkali ion migration path in the pristine graphite, FeCl<sub>3</sub>-GIC, and MoCl<sub>5</sub>-GIC from the top view. (j) Calculated activation energy curves of sodium ions along the interlamellar migration path. (k) Rate comparison of the current work and other carbon-based anode materials for SIBs. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, The Royal Society of Chemistry.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0110" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0110_R_d33609751e3021" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 110 - J. Mater. Chem. A">110</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               
               <p>To further enhance the performance of EG, materials with different compositions and structures have been constructed. Cai et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0109" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0109_R_d33609751e3029" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 109 - Chem. Eng. J.">109</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported a novel hierarchical micro-composite assembled from Bi nano/submicron spheres and EG flakes (H-BiS/EGF), which was synthesized through mechanical milling and heat treatment, as shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5e</a>. Electrochemical tests showed that the H-BiS/EGF micro-composite anode exhibited outstanding cycling stability (95% capacity retention for 17300 cycles at 5 A g<sup>–</sup><sup>1</sup>) and excellent rate capability (228 mAh g<sup>–</sup><sup>1</sup> at 25 A g<sup>–</sup><sup>1</sup>), as offered in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5f,g</a>. Li et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0110" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0110_R_d33609751e3050" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 110 - J. Mater. Chem. A">110</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> first reported MoCl<sub>5</sub>-intercalated GICs as a superior anode material for SIBs, and in this system, MoCl<sub>5</sub> molecular layers were intercalated and tightly immobilized between graphite layers to form MoCl<sub>5</sub>-GICs with adjustable Stage 1 and Stage 2 structures via the molten-salt synthesis method. The charge transfer models of the G2, G1, and graphite (G0) peaks in the G-band are schematically illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5h</a>. G2 means that the graphite layers were sandwiched on both sides by intercalant layers, while G1 represents graphite layers overlaid on one side with an intercalant guest layer. G0 indicates the original graphite layers without the intercalant guest contact.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0133" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0133_R_d33609751e3065" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 133 - ACS Nano">133</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Three deep understandings of ion mobility behavior in the crystal lattice were gained, which exhibit the optimum alkali ion migration paths in the interlayers of those materials as presented in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5i</a>, and their calculated activation energy (migration barrier) along the interlamellar migration paths was plotted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5j</a>. The result implied that the transport of Na ions in MoCl<sub>5</sub>-GIC was the most accessible and the fastest, thus leading to the best electrochemical storage performance, and particularly a rate performance comparison revealed that the high-rate capability of the MoCl<sub>5</sub>-GIC anode was superior to those of many other carbon-based SIB anodes reported so far (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0005">5k</a>). Additionally, In 2021, Kim et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0111" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0111_R_d33609751e3085" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 111 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">111</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported that MoS<sub>x</sub> can be inserted into the interlayers of EG by conversion reaction to generate EG-MoS<sub>x</sub> pillars. EG-MoS<sub>x</sub> anode with an enlarged interlayer of ∼5.38 Å delivered an exceptionally high specific capacity of 501 mAh g<sup>–</sup><sup>1</sup>. In addition to the above strategies (expanding the interlayer space and designing hybrid-composite), constructing defect engineering is another topic on graphite structure engineering. Lei et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0112" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0112_R_d33609751e3100" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 112 - Nanoscale">112</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed activated graphite by forming abundant defects, and combined with experimental results and DFT calculations, the defects introduced by the ball-milling process are favorable for sodium adsorption by adjusting the appropriate adsorption energy. Jian et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0113" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0113_R_d33609751e3105" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 113 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">113</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> fabricated highly defective graphite and studied the mechanisms for sodium storage. The improved ability in terms of specific capacity and cyclability (128.7 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> and over 8000 cycles with no decay at 5 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>) revealed the excellent adsorption behavior of Na ion, which was promoted by many defects. As we all know, graphite has kept being the dominating anode material for LIBs in the past few decades, while its study for SIBs is still in its infancy. The differences between sodium and lithium like atomic radius, stability of their GIC, thermodynamics, and so on, lead to a great diversity of design strategies. The modification of graphite materials has greatly improved the electrochemical properties of the anode. However, these enhancements required complex multistep processes with low yields, therefore it is currently a need to explore methods that could be used in large-scale production.</p>
               </section>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0070">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0070-title">3.1.3 Nanocarbon materials</h4>
               
               <p>Apart from the aforementioned carbonaceous materials, as alternative carbon materials, different scales and structures of carbon also can be the promising anode for SIBs. Significantly, nano-dimensions with specific morphology endow them with unique physical and chemical properties: high ion conductivity, good thermal conductivity, and outstanding mechanical properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0134" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0134_R_d33609751e3129" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 134 - Chem. – Asian J.">134</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> It is widely accepted that Nanocarbon materials with controllable morphology and size such as zero-dimensional (0D) carbon quantum dots,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0114" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0114_R_d33609751e3134" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 114 - ACS Appl. Nano Mater.">114</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0115" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0115_R_d33609751e3134" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 115 - Electrochim. Acta">115</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> one-dimensional (1D) carbon nanofibers/nanotubes,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0025" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0025_R_d33609751e3139" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 25 - Small">25</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0116" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0116_R_d33609751e3139" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 116 - Carbon">116</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0135_R_d33609751e3139" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Carbon">135</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0136" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0136_R_d33609751e3139" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 136 - Nano Energy">136</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> two-dimensional (2D) carbon nanosheets,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0117" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0117_R_d33609751e3145" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 117 - Carbon">117</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0120" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0120_R_d33609751e3145" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 120 - Small">120</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and three-dimensional (3D) porous carbon nanostructure<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0121" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0121_R_d33609751e3150" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 121 - Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.">121</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0137_R_d33609751e3150" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> contribute to good rate capability as anode materials for SIBs, owing to the decreased Na ion diffusion distance, high Na ion diffusion coefficient, and fast electron transport. Varying dimensions of carbon show their distinctive sodium storage mechanisms, such as the charging/discharging curves of sodium storage in nanosheets are sloping-shaped without an obvious potential plateau, indicating that the sodium storage on nanosheets exhibits surface adsorption (capacitive) behavior and the charge/discharge curves of carbon nanotubes as anode material for SIBs is sloping. The sodium storage mechanisms are mainly based on the sodium adsorption on the surface or defects.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0138" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0138_R_d33609751e3156" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 138 - J. Power Sources">138</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, the achievements in designing nanocarbon are still insufficient, and plenty of modification strategies have been explored to improve specific capacity or rate capability via doping, adjusting the interlayer spacing, and so forth. Moreover, it is all known that precursors determine the nature of products, and biomass materials nowadays have attracted much attention due to the abundance of resources, low cost, rapid regeneration, and sustainability. Most importantly, biomasses feature unique microstructures and compositions, and the resultant biomass-derived carbons usually retain the diversity of their structures and compositions after pyrolysis.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0139" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0139_R_d33609751e3161" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 139 - Nanomaterials">139</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0002">2</a> summarizes a variety of recently reported nanocarbon anode materials for SIBs in terms of practical capacity, initial Coulombic efficiency, and cycling stability.</p>
               
               <p>Yang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0122" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0122_R_d33609751e3172" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 122 - Energy Storage Mater.">122</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> demonstrated a highly efficient, convenient, and low-cost strategy to fabricate a 3D interconnected carbon nanofibers (CNFs) film by direct carbonization using bacterial cellulose (BC) as a precursor, which can directly be employed as a self-supported and binder-free anode, as shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0006">6a</a>. BC is a typical biomass material produced by microbial fermentation, consisting of an ultrafine interconnected 3D porous network structure composed of nanofibers. The CNFs obtained at a carbonization temperature of 1300°C (CNFs-1300) showed the best electrochemical performance, delivering an ultralong cycle life (105 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 10,000 cycles with a specific capacity decay of 0.003% per cycle) and outstanding ICE (93%) in SIBs. The author also investigated the sodium storage routes of CNFs-1300 in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0006">6b</a> and proposed an adsorption and co-intercalation mechanism. During first discharging to 0.2 V, Na ions first adsorbed on the material surfaces and partly inserted into the edge of graphitic-like domains, relating to the slope region-specific capacity. When further discharging to a lower voltage (0.001 V), Na ions and solvent molecules could co-intercalate in the graphitic-like segments, corresponding to the plateau region-specific capacity. During the desodiation process, Na ions were first extracted from the graphitic-like segments (charging to 0.2 V) and then from the edge of graphitic-like domains (charging to 2.5 V). Magnolia petals were used as the precursor by Yu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0140" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0140_R_d33609751e3187" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 140 - New J. Chem.">140</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and ZnCl<sub>2</sub> as the template and activator, to prepare porous biomass carbon materials directly through one-step carbonization. The as-prepared coralloid magnolia-based porous carbon materials demonstrated a coral-like, three-dimensional cross-linked carbon nanostructure, similar to its original form with a high specific surface area and an abundant pore structure, exhibiting outstanding electrochemical properties. Lu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0123" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0123_R_d33609751e3194" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 123 - Ind. Eng. Chem. Res.">123</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> fabricated novel S-doped carbon nanosheets (SCNs) by using starch and graphene oxide (GO) as the carbon source and matrix, respectively. The obtained SCNs exhibited hierarchical pores and a sandwich-like structure, hence showing a highly reversible discharging specific capacity of 207.3 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 100 cycles at 50 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> as well as long-term cycling stability of more than 500 cycles. In addition to the biomass precursors above, alginate,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0124" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0124_R_d33609751e3206" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 124 - Front. Chem.">124</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> leaves,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0125" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0125_R_d33609751e3211" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 125 - Electrochim. Acta">125</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and bagasse<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0126" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0126_R_d33609751e3217" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 126 - Nanomaterials">126</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have been utilized to prepare carbon anode materials for SIBs as well. Generally, biomass materials tend to contain some heteroatoms (e.g., O, N, S, and P) which are the important elements for sodium storage, and thus the derived carbon materials doped with these heteroatoms can be directly obtained by carbonizing treatment.</p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0006"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/6f035004-b682-42bd-a6a4-36f4c2501814/cnl2171-fig-0006-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/6f035004-b682-42bd-a6a4-36f4c2501814/cnl2171-fig-0006-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/11115287-c614-472e-9db5-91ae11a3c1ad/cnl2171-fig-0006-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/6f035004-b682-42bd-a6a4-36f4c2501814/cnl2171-fig-0006-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 6<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0006&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Schematic illustration of the synthesis process of CNFs. (b) Schematic illustration of the sodiation and desodiation processes. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0122" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0122_R_d33609751e3242" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 122 - Energy Storage Mater.">122</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (c) Schematic illustration of the formation and variation of interlayer spacing of N-CNTs. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2022, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0127" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0127_R_d33609751e3247" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 127 - Chem. Eng. J.">127</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (d) Schematic illustration of the synthesis of the 3D scaffolding framework of S-doped carbon nanosheets and their application for SIBs. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0128" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0128_R_d33609751e3252" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 128 - Nano Energy">128</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (e) Schematic of the preparation of CNFs and S-CNFs. (f) Schematic of the sodium storage mechanism of S-CNFs. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, The Royal Society of Chemistry.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0065" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0065_R_d33609751e3258" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 65 - J. Mater. Chem. A">65</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               
               <p>Heteroatom doping is a strategy to effectively enhance the sodium storage properties of carbon materials. The introduction of heteroatoms, that is, boron (B), phosphorus (P), nitrogen (N) sulfur (S), and fluorine (F), and so forth into the backbone of the respective carbon material can generate extrinsic defects and change carbon lattices, thus improving their reaction kinetics and electrochemical performance by tuning the electronic and chemical properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0129" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0129_R_d33609751e3266" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 129 - Adv. Mater.">129</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0132" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0132_R_d33609751e3266" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 132 - ACS Nano">132</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Besides, biomass materials generally contain some heteroatoms (e.g., O, N, S, and P), and the derived carbon materials doped with these heteroatoms can be directly obtained by carbonizing treatment.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0141" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0141_R_d33609751e3271" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 141 - Adv. Energy Mater.">141</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Thus, a variety of heteroatom-doped carbonaceous materials have been widely explored as anode materials for SIBs. The most commonly introduced element in carbon materials is nitrogen, which can significantly improve their rate properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0141" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0141_R_d33609751e3276" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 141 - Adv. Energy Mater.">141</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The N-doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNTs) were synthesized through facile one-step pyrolysis of g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> precursor assisted by Ni catalyst,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0127" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0127_R_d33609751e3286" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 127 - Chem. Eng. J.">127</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0006">6c</a>. The obtained N-CNTs displayed a unique 1D nanotubular structure, high electrical conductivity, suitable N-doping around 8.73 ~ 14.72 at%, and tunable interlayer distance up to 0.462 nm, which can accommodate sufficiently Na ions. Attractive N-doped porous carbon nanosheets (NPCs-4) were synthesized by a simple one-step carbonization approach using the mixtures of melamine cyanurate and xylitol, which formed the interconnected carbon framework with a large specific surface area (703.2 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>) and expanded interlayer spacing of ~0.39 nm.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0130" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0130_R_d33609751e3300" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 130 - Diamond Relat. Mater.">130</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> N-doping of the NPCs-4 facilitated high sodium storage capacity, fast transfer kinetics, and stable cycling. As a result of these improvements, the as-prepared NPCs-4 anode delivered an outstanding ultra-long cycling performance with a specific capacity of 171 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 10 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 10000 cycles (0.0017% loss per cycle). Phosphorus elemental is known to be electrochemically active. It affects not only the electronic state but also the microstructure of the carbon material. Sun et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0142" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0142_R_d33609751e3312" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 142 - J. Alloys Compd.">142</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported a facile synthesis of P-doped carbon nanosheets derived from coal pitch with sheet thickness of ca. 8 nm using sodium hypophosphite as an assistant and phosphorus source. Together with the ultra-thin sheet and the P-doped properties, the obtained carbon nanosheet as SIB anodes displayed ultrafast charging-discharge specific capacity with superior long-term cycling ability. Superior to introducing N and P atoms, S-doping can afford multiple advantages simultaneously, mainly including additional Faradaic reactions to improve the sodium storage specific capacity, enlarged specific surface area SSA to provide more reaction sites, increased electronegativity, and better electrical conductivity, and expanded interlayer distance to facilitate Na ion absorption and transfer in the charge/discharge processes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0129" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0129_R_d33609751e3317" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 129 - Adv. Mater.">129</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> As shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0006">6d</a>, Zhao et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0128" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0128_R_d33609751e3326" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 128 - Nano Energy">128</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported S-doped 3D scaffolding framework of carbon nanosheets (S-CNS) by one-step pyrolyzation, with plant biomass (spring onion peel, SOP) and S powder as the precursors. Due to the dominance above, the resultant S-CNS anode with high heteroatoms-doping level (~23%), expanded interlayer spacing (~0.38 nm), large assessable specific surface area delivered an ultrahigh reversible specific capacity of 605 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, high-rate performance 133 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> and long-term cycling stability at 5 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> (~94% retention upon 2000 cycles). Moreover, they also demonstrate that such S-doped carbon materials with competent electrochemical properties can be easily produced from diverse plant wastes including onion skin, garlic peel, elm samara, and lotus leaf using this method. Besides, utilizing sulfur powder as an S resource, Jin et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0065" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0065_R_d33609751e3341" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 65 - J. Mater. Chem. A">65</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported a high-performance SIB anode of S-doped interconnected carbon nanofibers (denoted as S-CNFs), which was directly derived from the industrial waste product bacterial cellulose (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0006">6e</a>). First, the cross-linked carbon nanofibers provided a large contact area and reduced the Na ion diffusion distance, owing to the synergistic effect of interconnected carbon nanofibers, effective S-doping, and stable carbon networks, as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0006">6f</a>. Second, S doping not only effectively enlarged the carbon interlayer spacing from 0.386 to 0.410 nm, but also enhanced the specific capacity through the electrochemically active -C-S-C- bonds. Third, the robust interconnected carbon nanofiber networks facilitated the structural integrity of the anode. In addition, the theoretical calculations demonstrated the improved mobility of Na ions and decreased bandgap and formation energy owing to S doping. Hence, The S-CNFs anode presents high reversible capacities of 460 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.05 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> and 255 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 10 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, as well as a specific capacity of 310 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 1100 cycles.</p>
               
               <p>Compared with single-element doping, the co-doping of two or more heteroatoms further could improve the electrochemical performance, because it allows the advantages of each element to be synergistically utilized. Since N doping improves electrical conductivity and contact area with active materials/electrolytes, and S and P doping enlarges the interlayer distance and introduces amounts of defects, research efforts are devoted to achieving N/S-co-doping and N/P-co-doping to achieve better sodium storage performance. Wang and colleagues<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0126" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0126_R_d33609751e3376" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 126 - Nanomaterials">126</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared N/S-co-doped porous carbon sheets (N/S-CS) via a simple thermal treatment method, using KOH-treated waste bagasse as a carbon source, and thiourea as the N and S precursor. Due to the effect of the co-doping of N and S, abundant defects were induced to enhance electrical conductivity, shortening the diffusion distance of Na ions, and increasing sodium storage sites. It was evident that the N/S-CS showed excellent sodium storage performance with a high reversible specific capacity, good rate capability, and stable cycling performance (retaining 155 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> for 2000 cycles). Wang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0131" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0131_R_d33609751e3388" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 131 - Carbon">131</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared a dense 3D porous carbon network with high-level N, P co-doping (NPC) through a facile chemical crosslinking of bacterial cellulose (BC) with hexachlorocyclotriphosphazene (HCCP) and subsequent calcination. The co-doping of N and S not only promoted sodium adsorption ability but also enhanced electrical conductivity, endowing NPC anode a superior reversible gravimetric specific capacity (223 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.05 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>) and rate performance (145 mAhg<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 10 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 1000 cycles).</p>
               
               <p>Compared with graphite, it is worth noting that nanodimension carbon undergoes great progress. To further enhance the performance and decrease cost, the following research directions can be chosen: (i) For large-scale practical application, the carbon precursors should be cheap, therefore the biowastes (banana peels, corn cobs, and peanut shells) would be ideal precursor choices for carbon anodes. (ii) Appreciable micromorphology is essential for carbon materials to be endowed with excellent properties. Especially for biomass-derived carbon, it is appropriate to select precursors with unique structures, which can directly determine the structure/morphology of the products to promote sodium storage properties. (iii) Based on this, the preparation method under low temperatures should be applied, as under high temperatures, the heteroatoms would become unstable and even diminish the effect of doping. After modification, it is believed that the approaches for fabricating nanostructure carbon anodes is closer to practical application.</p>
               </section>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0080">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="cnl2171-sec-0080-title">3.2 Phosphorus-based materials</h3>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0090">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0090-title">3.2.1 Red phosphorus (RP)</h4>
               
               <p>Since the first report of RP as an anode material for SIBs in 2013,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0143" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0143_R_d33609751e3423" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 143 - Adv. Mater.">143</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> it was considered to be a promising candidate due to its preferable properties, including a high theoretical specific capacity of ~2600 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, a relatively low redox operating potential of ~0.4 V versus Na/Na<sup>+</sup>, nature abundance, and low cost.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0144" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0144_R_d33609751e3434" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 144 - Nano Res.">144</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0146" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0146_R_d33609751e3434" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 146 - J. Mater. Sci. Technol.">146</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Generally speaking, RP exhibits three distinct transitional structures, including amorphous form, crystalline form, and an intermediate state between amorphous and crystalline. Compared with crystalline RP, the amorphous form exhibits a leg up in adopting volume changes during the charge/discharge processes. The main sodium storage mechanism is alloying/dealloying,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0147" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0147_R_d33609751e3439" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 147 - Energy Storage Mater.">147</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> which is responsible for the most contribution of the specific capacity of SIBs. Both P atoms and Na atoms undergo a stepwise sodiation process, forming the alloying products Na<sub>3</sub>P phase, which generates a high specific capacity. However, the pristine RP also suffers some major challenges such as low electronic conductivity (1 × 10<sup>−</sup><sup>14</sup> S cm<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0148" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0148_R_d33609751e3453" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 148 - J. Mater. Chem. A">148</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and it causes sluggish reaction kinetics, low utilization of the phosphorus in the anode, and large volume changes (300%–500%) during sodiation/desodiation processes, which causes significant pulverization of the anode and rapid structural degradation. In addition, the ultimate product of sodiation Na<sub>3</sub>P also showed low electrical conductivity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0149" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0149_R_d33609751e3460" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 149 - J. Mater. Chem. A">149</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The above fatal drawbacks lead to poor rate performance and shortened cycle lifespans, greatly hindering the application of RP as an SIB anode. To settle these obstacles, mass efforts have been made to enhance the electrochemical performance, such as composite design,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0146" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0146_R_d33609751e3466" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 146 - J. Mater. Sci. Technol.">146</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0150" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0150_R_d33609751e3466" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 150 - Nat. Commun.">150</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0151" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0151_R_d33609751e3466" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 151 - Energy Storage Mater.">151</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> nanostructure engineering,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0152" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0152_R_d33609751e3471" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 152 - ACS Nano">152</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0153" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0153_R_d33609751e3471" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 153 - ACS Nano">153</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> surface modification,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0154" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0154_R_d33609751e3477" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 154 - Nano Energy">154</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and so forth, as summarized in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0003">3</a>.</p>
               
               <div class="article-table-content" id="cnl2171-tbl-0003">

                              <td class="left-aligned">89.5</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">92.5% (1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 100 cycles)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0046" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0046_R_d33609751e4076" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 46 - ACS Nano">46</a></span>]</td>
                              </tr>
                           </tbody>
                        </table>
                  </div>
                  
                  <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
               </div>
               <p>Compositing RP with various types of materials was believed to improve their poor electrical conducitvity. It can not only combine the characteristics of each component synergistically but also construct a heterostructure to improve reaction kinetics. It can not only combine the characteristics of each component synergistically but also construct a heterostructure to improve electrical conductivity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0165" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0165_R_d33609751e4086" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 165 - Energy Storage Mater.">165</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Carbonaceous materials were always viewed as a good conductive matrix ascribing to their large surface area, high electrical conductivity, and superior mechanical stability. Apart from that, carbonaceous materials can also relatively easily form a substantial porous structure to mitigate the severe volume expansion of RP during cycling, preventing the anode from pulverization and alleviating the structural degradation.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0166" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0166_R_d33609751e4091" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 166 - Small">166</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Zhang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0155" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0155_R_d33609751e4096" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 155 - J. Power Sources">155</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> encapsulated RP in N-doped multicavity carbon (NMC) via a surface-free energy-driven self-assembly strategy, as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7a</a>, and such a unique structure provided large space to buffer the stress caused by RP volume expansion and enables fast electron transport, enhancing the electrical conductivity. The Na ion insertion mechanism is fundamentally the same as the aforementioned stepwise reaction (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7b</a>). What is interesting was that Na<sub>2</sub>C<sub>60</sub> was produced during the discharge process, which can be recognized as a buffer medium that facilitated the cyclic stabilization of the anode, maintaining a high specific capacity of 923.7 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 1000 cycles at a current density of 0.5 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, as given in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7c</a>. Among all the morphologies of carbon materials, carbon nanocages (CNCs) with distinctive properties of large surface area, mass interior cavities, and high conductivity, become ideal hosts for RP encapsulation, providing large voids for volume changes, mass RP loading, and rapid electron transport.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0167" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0167_R_d33609751e4122" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 167 - Nat. Commun.">167</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0168" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0168_R_d33609751e4122" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 168 - Adv. Mater.">168</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> It is believed that nano-sized materials show greater stability and faster Na ion diffusion, which are beneficial to the electrochemical performance.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0169" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0169_R_d33609751e4128" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 169 - Energy Environ. Sci.">169</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0170" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0170_R_d33609751e4128" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 170 - Small">170</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Liu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0156" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0156_R_d33609751e4133" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 156 - ACS Nano">156</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> also reported a controllable strategy to encapsulate nanoscaled RP into conductive and networked carbon nanocages (denoted as RP@CNCs) using a combination of a phosphorus-amine-based method and an evacuation-filling process. Benefiting from the synergic effects of the interior cavities and conductive network, the RP@CNC composite anode presented a splendid long cycling performance with capacity retention of over 80% after 1300 cycles at 5000 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Similarly, reduced graphite oxide aerogel (rGA) displayed high electrical conductivity, surface area, and flexibility, which could likewise serve as a conductive matrix to incorporate RP. As shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7d</a>, Yan et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0157" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0157_R_d33609751e4145" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 157 - Chem. Eng. J.">157</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> successfully confined crystalline RP (CRP) nanorods within 3D rGO aerogel (3D rGA) via prepositioned nanoseeds followed by a secondary growth method. Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7e</a> shows the schematic illustration of the charge/discharge processes of CRP, which suggests that almost all the phosphorus in the anode reacted with sodium to yield Na<sub>3</sub>P. Owing to the high dispersion of CRP in rGA and the strong interaction between CRP and rGA. CRP-rGA anode delivered high specific capacities of 918 and 860 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 1.0 and 2.0 A g<sup>−1</sup> after 30 cycles, respectively, demonstrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7f</a>. CNTs, appearing as single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), could also combine with phosphorus to form hybrid architectures. A 3D N-doped stripped-G CNT (denoted as N-SGCNT) with the hierarchical pores structure was designed to confine different ultrafine-P contents in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7g</a> and expecting that the in situ cross-linked 1D@2D structure of the N-SGCNT matrix can prevent the agglomeration of P and ensure a larger amount of ultrafine P particles to be uniformly confined. Corresponding to the experimental results, SGCNT with medium P contents delivered sufficient available space to accompany the volume inflation of P during the discharge/charge processes and presents high electrical conductivity (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7h</a>). Although the pristine RP was relatively stable, oxidation still occurs slowly in the air, generating phosphorus oxides.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0165" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0165_R_d33609751e4171" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 165 - Energy Storage Mater.">165</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> To further improve the loading mass of RP and achieve high energy density for commercial RP, it was assembled into CNTs, which are derived from natural wood by Zhu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0048" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0048_R_d33609751e4176" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 48 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">48</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The unique hierarchical framework with low tortuosity, high cross-linked conductive, and ultrahigh RP mass loading (14.1 mg cm<sup>−</sup><sup>2</sup>) not only contributed to restricting the growth of RP large particles but also showed superior conductivity for both ions and electrons. Meanwhile, in addition to carbon materials, conductive polymers can be used as functional components to overcome the problems of RP materials. Based on the above factors, Fang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0154" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0154_R_d33609751e4185" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 154 - Nano Energy">154</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized a RP@activated carbon@polypyrrole (RP@AC@PPy) composite by a vaporization-deposition-conversion (VDC) method, as shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7i</a>. Compared to single-layer protection, under the joint protection of AC and PPy, this anode not only isolated the superficial red P from the electrolyte but also restrained the volume changes, which was beneficial to guaranteeing stable structure during cycling and oxidation resistance when exposed to air (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0007">7i</a>), and it thus exhibited an excellent specific capacity of 220 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.2 A g<sup>−1</sup> after 60 days for SIBs.</p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0007"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/1bcd6dfc-4f8e-490f-a721-47529397d096/cnl2171-fig-0007-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/1bcd6dfc-4f8e-490f-a721-47529397d096/cnl2171-fig-0007-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/c25d0ff0-38b6-4f0d-8772-b5c2428ca85e/cnl2171-fig-0007-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/1bcd6dfc-4f8e-490f-a721-47529397d096/cnl2171-fig-0007-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 7<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0007&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Representative illustration of red P enveloped multicavity carbon spheres composite. (b) Representative illustration of the electrochemical reaction processes for the P@NMC. (c) Cycling capability of P@NMC with prolonged cycle life (1000 cycles) at 0.5 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0155" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0155_R_d33609751e4224" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 155 - J. Power Sources">155</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (d) Schematic illustration of the synthesis procedure of CRP-rGA. (e) Schematic illustration of the charge/discharge processes of CRP. (f) Cycling performance of CRP-rGA (1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 2 Ag<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>) and commercial RP (1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>). Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0157" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0157_R_d33609751e4239" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 157 - Chem. Eng. J.">157</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (g) Illustration of the synthetic route for P@N-SGCNT composites. (h) Schematic illustration of the reversible reaction mechanisms of the P@N-SGCNT composites. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, American Chemical Society.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0158" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0158_R_d33609751e4245" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 158 - ACS Nano">158</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (i) Schematic illustration of the fabrication processes of red P@AC and red P@AC@PPy composite. (j) Schematic illustration of the sodiation processes of P@AC and P@AC@PPy in PIBs/SIBs and their (anti-) oxidation upon exposure to air. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020 Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0154" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0154_R_d33609751e4250" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 154 - Nano Energy">154</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               </section>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0100">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0100-title">3.2.2 Black phosphorus (BP)</h4>
               
               <p>Compared to red phosphorus, BP is a typical two-dimensional layered structure, which exhibits a larger layer distance (0.53 nm) than graphite (0.335 nm) counterpart to facilitate the insertion of Na ions into the interlayers.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0171" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0171_R_d33609751e4264" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 171 - Appl. Phys. A.">171</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Moreover, it is traced that BP usually shows an orthorhombic crystallinity. Specifically, each phosphorus atom could be covalently bonded with three adjacent phosphorus atoms, forming a puckered honeycomb structure in a single layer of BP.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0172" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0172_R_d33609751e4269" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 172 - Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.">172</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> As the SIB anode, BP exhibits an extremely high electrical conductivity (~300 S m<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>), similarly high theoretical specific capacity to RP (~2600 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0159" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0159_R_d33609751e4281" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 159 - Nano Lett.">159</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0173" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0173_R_d33609751e4281" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 173 - Nano Lett.">173</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and a suitable sodiation potential windows versus Na/Na<sup>+</sup>. At the same time, BP displays similar sodiation reaction mechanisms with RP, both of which can form Na<sub>3</sub>P after the discharge process.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0174" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0174_R_d33609751e4291" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 174 - J. Mater. Chem. A">174</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, poor ion dynamics severely normally decrease reversible specific capacity and increase volume changes (300%–500%) during the discharge/charge processes, resulting in active materials pulverization and rapidly degraded cycling stability.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0175" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0175_R_d33609751e4296" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 175 - Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.">175</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, BP is more prone to be oxidized in the ambient than other typical 2D materials and reacts with water in the following reactions, producing phosphorus ions to exclusively degrade BP and generate increased contact impedance and mechanical properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0176" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0176_R_d33609751e4301" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - Nat. Mater.">176</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0179" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0179_R_d33609751e4301" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 179 - J. Am. Chem. Soc.">179</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> To be honest, these formidable drawbacks are deemed to retard its application in practice.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0180" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0180_R_d33609751e4307" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Mater. Adv.">180</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0181" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0181_R_d33609751e4307" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 181 - Energy Storage Mater.">181</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <p>Toward this end, various design strategies have been carried out as summarized in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0003">3</a>. In 2017, Zhang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0182" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0182_R_d33609751e4317" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 182 - Nano Energy">182</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> developed a nanoscale surface engineering strategy to in situ polymerize 3,4ethylenedioxythiophene (EDOT) molecules on the surface of surface-modified few-layer BP nanosheets (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0008">8a</a>). Such a material design not only optimized charge transfer, but also simultaneously realized super surface wettability with the electrolyte, showing a significant enhancement of cycling performance (1092 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 100 cycles at 100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>), as evidenced in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0008">8b</a>. In another study, Zhang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0160" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0160_R_d33609751e4335" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 160 - Mater. Chem. Front.">160</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> utilized the strong interface interactions to construct MoS<sub>2</sub>/BP heterostructure, and due to the synergistic effect of the heterostructure, enhanced electron/ion transport kinetics and improved structure stability upon discharge/charge processes were simultaneously carried out, contributing to superior sodium storage performance. Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>, as the anode material, exhibited good stability and gradually gained attention in SIBs in the past few years. Li&nbsp;et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0161" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0161_R_d33609751e4347" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 161 - Nanoscale">161</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared the BP/Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub> Mxene composite by combining BP nanoparticles and Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub> nanoflakes. Thanks to the stable interfacial interaction of BP and Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>, the resistance of electrons was reduced, and Na ion transport was promoted. To further mitigate the capacity decay, and improve cycling stability, Song et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0162" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0162_R_d33609751e4365" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 162 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">162</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> fabricated sulfur-doped black phosphorus-TiO<sub>2</sub> hybrids (TiO<sub>2</sub>-BP-S) utilizing the high-energy ball milling method, as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0008">8c</a>. Considering the existence of stable P-S bonds with sulfur and strong P-Ti bonds with TiO<sub>2</sub>, BP enhanced air stability and suppressed volume expansion, as shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0008">8d,e</a>. Therefore, the anode displayed a long cycling property, and its discharge-specific capacity can reach 290 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 500 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 600 cycles.</p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0008"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/98da0850-871c-4c15-bf2f-5db96e110435/cnl2171-fig-0008-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/98da0850-871c-4c15-bf2f-5db96e110435/cnl2171-fig-0008-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/a37decd6-b8cb-448c-8426-fef09ece7d83/cnl2171-fig-0008-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/98da0850-871c-4c15-bf2f-5db96e110435/cnl2171-fig-0008-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 8<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0008&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Preparation steps of E-BP/PEDOT architecture. (b) Cycling performance of the E-BP/PEDOT and E-BP anodes and their corresponding CEs at 100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2017, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0182" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0182_R_d33609751e4413" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 182 - Nano Energy">182</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (c) Scheme of the ball-milling treatment of materials with or without sulfur. (d) P-S bonds and P-Ti bonds inhibit the volume expansion of TiO<sub>2</sub>-BP-S hybrids. (e) HRTEM images of TiO<sub>2</sub>-BP-S hybrids. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0162" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0162_R_d33609751e4423" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 162 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">162</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (f) Schematic of the fabrication process of Se-BP@TiO<sub>2</sub>/C. (g) Schematic amorphous structure for ion diffusion. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2022, American Chemical Society.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0163" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0163_R_d33609751e4430" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 163 - Inorg. Chem.">163</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (h) Schematic diagram of the sodiation of BP-G and BP-G/PANI anodes. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, American Chemical Society.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0164" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0164_R_d33609751e4436" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 164 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">164</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               
               <p>It is well known that the sluggish reaction kinetics of BP is the key challenge, impeding its application in the anode of SIBs, constructing heterostructure has been confirmed to effectively tackle that issue.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0183" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0183_R_d33609751e4444" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 183 - J. Mater. Chem. A">183</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0185" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0185_R_d33609751e4444" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 185 - eScience">185</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Xu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0163" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0163_R_d33609751e4449" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 163 - Inorg. Chem.">163</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> successfully fabricated the heterostructure of Se-doped BP and MOF-derived TiO<sub>2</sub>/C (Se-BP@TiO<sub>2</sub>/C), taking full use of the merits of each ternary component such as the abundance of active sites at the heterointerfaces and enhancing kinetics by built-in electric fields, as demonstrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0008">8f</a>. Via the Se-assist ball-milling method, electrical conductivity was improved by the doped S, and more importantly, the S powders contributed to the amorphization of BP and TiO<sub>2</sub>, which offered large free volume to buffer the volume changes of anode materials and acted as channels for ion diffusion (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0008">8g</a>). Integrating with carbonaceous material is the most common and effective way to enhance electrical conductivity. As demonstrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0008">8h</a>, Wan and colleagues<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0164" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0164_R_d33609751e4471" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 164 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">164</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed a ternary composition containing few-layer BP flakes, graphite, and polyaniline (BP-G/PANI) with a high BP mass content of 65 wt%, displaying a high reversible capacity. Within the elaborate ternary composition, graphite in the BP-G hybrid reduced the charge transfer resistance and enhanced the P utilization (around 90%) during the sodiation/desodiation processes, and PANI with a uniform coating layer showed swelling properties in the electrolyte, enabling excellent ion accessibility and high reversible capacity at a high rate as well as accommodating the volume expansion. Therefore, an optimized Na-ion pathway (electrolyte→PANI→BP-G→BP) between the electrolyte and active material (BP-G) was realized. Due to the above characteristics, the BP-G/PANI composite anode presented remarkable electrochemical performance with a high overall reversible specific capacity of 520 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 1000 cycles at a high rate of 4 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Considering the fact of practical work condition, it is important to develop air-stabilized P-based anode materials.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0186" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0186_R_d33609751e4482" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 186 - Adv. Mater.">186</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0187" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0187_R_d33609751e4482" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 187 - ACS Nano">187</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Ma et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0188" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0188_R_d33609751e4488" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 188 - Mater. Today">188</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> constructed an unique red@black phosphorus core-shell heterostructure anchored on the 3D N-doped graphene (RP@BP-3DNG) via a facile one-step solvothermal strategy. The fromed built-in fields at the interfaces of red and black phosphorus promoted the shift of electron cloud from BP to RP, greatly suppressing the reaction activity of lone-pair electrons of BP atoms. Consequencely, RP@BP-3DNG exhibited a high charge specific capacity of 1233.6 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> with an ICE of 55.2% as well as stable cycling over 500 cycles at 10.0 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after exposed in air. Like black phosphorus and red phosphorus, metal phosphides also suffer a significantly low resistance to air, which lead to the composition change. Park et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0189" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0189_R_d33609751e4500" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 189 - Nanoscale">189</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed a densely packed film of FeP with the protection of hydrophobic rGO and graphitic carbon. Interstingly, the dual protection layers acted as a barrier to protect the FeP nanoparticles from oxidation, showing a great cycling capability with a low capacity decay (94.6% after 1000 cycles at 1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>), and a high rate capability (440.7 mA h g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 5 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>).</p>
               
               <p>In the past several years, the research progress made on phosphorus-based composite in SIBs is substantial because of their high theoretical specific capacity, nature abundance, low cost, nontoxicity as well as relative suable operating voltage windows. However, some significant challenges remain, and the following challenges are required to be settled: (1) The Na ion insertion/de-insertion mechanism is still unclear and controversial, and hardly any direct experimental results prove the mechanism proposed by the researchers. (2) It is necessary to figure out the mechanisms of terrible volumetric expansions, because it has significantly hindered the full utilization of phosphorus-based anode with high theoretical specific capacities. (3) Although researchers have developed numerous preparation methods to further increase the P content, and still no suitable economical, and controllable preparation method has been found. (4) Researchers have devised many strategies to prepare phosphorus, including the ball-milling method,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0151" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0151_R_d33609751e4519" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 151 - Energy Storage Mater.">151</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> gas-phase transformation,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0190" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0190_R_d33609751e4524" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 190 - J. Cryst. Grow.">190</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0191" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0191_R_d33609751e4524" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 191 - J. Solid State Chem.">191</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> high-pressure and high-temperature methods,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0046" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0046_R_d33609751e4529" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 46 - ACS Nano">46</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0192" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0192_R_d33609751e4529" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 192 - Adv. Sci.">192</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0193" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0193_R_d33609751e4529" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 193 - Nanoscale">193</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and vaporization-condensation,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0194" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0194_R_d33609751e4535" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 194 - Chem. Commun.">194</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0195" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0195_R_d33609751e4535" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 195 - ChemElectroChem">195</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> but all of these synthesis have their advantages and shortcoming, such as low yield with unsatisfactory quality, complex device required and methodologies, high cost, and increased safety risks. It is foreseeable that in the future there will remain a large number of research reports on the composition design, structural engineering, and surface modification of red phosphorus to greatly enhance its electrochemical properties.</p>
               </section>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0110">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0110-title">3.2.3 Metal phosphides (MP<sub>x</sub>)</h4>
               
               <div class="paragraph-element">MP<sub>x</sub>, incorporating P atoms and other metal atoms through chemical bonds, such as Fe (FeP,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0196" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0196_R_d33609751e4553" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 196 - RSC Adv.">196</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0198" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0198_R_d33609751e4553" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 198 - ACS Nano">198</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> FeP<sub>4</sub><sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0199" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0199_R_d33609751e4559" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 199 - Electrochem. Commun.">199</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), Ni (Ni<sub>2</sub>P,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0200" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0200_R_d33609751e4567" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 200 - J. Alloys Compd.">200</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0201" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0201_R_d33609751e4567" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 201 - J. Alloys Compd.">201</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Ni<sub>3</sub>P,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0202" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0202_R_d33609751e4574" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 202 - J. Mater. Chem. A">202</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0203" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0203_R_d33609751e4574" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 203 - J. Mater. Chem. A">203</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Ni<sub>12</sub>P<sub>5</sub><sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0204" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0204_R_d33609751e4583" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 204 - J. Mater. Chem. A">204</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), Cu (CuP<sub>2</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0205" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0205_R_d33609751e4590" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 205 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">205</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Cu<sub>3</sub>P<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0206" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0206_R_d33609751e4598" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 206 - J. Alloys Compd.">206</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0207" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0207_R_d33609751e4598" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 207 - Rare Met.">207</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), and Ge (GeP<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0208" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0208_R_d33609751e4603" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 208 - J. Power Sources">208</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0209" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0209_R_d33609751e4603" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 209 - Adv. Energy Mater.">209</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), demonstrate a favorable electrochemical performance, including such as high theoretical energy density/gravimetric specific capacity, low redox potential versus Na/Na<sup>+</sup>, and high electrical conductivity, when used as a SIB anodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0149" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0149_R_d33609751e4611" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 149 - J. Mater. Chem. A">149</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0210" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0210_R_d33609751e4611" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 210 - Adv. Sci.">210</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Due to incorporating various metal atoms, MP<sub>x</sub> features different structural characteristics, composition, and morphology, triggering distinctive electrochemical properties. Besides, the working mechanisms vary significantly, typically involving conversion reactions and alloying reactions. It can be divided into four major categories based on whether the metal elements in MP<sub>x</sub> react with sodium. When both the non-P element (M) and P phase in the phosphides react with sodium, it is called metal-active phosphides, and the M-P bond is broken. It is noted that metallic nanocrystals and the Na<sub>x</sub>P phase are formed during the initial discharge process through a conversion process, and the P phase in the subsequent cycles reacts with sodium until it is completely alloyed through a reversible alloying process. The corresponding reaction processes can be proposed as follows<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0211" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0211_R_d33609751e4623" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 211 - Nano Lett.">211</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0213" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0213_R_d33609751e4623" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 213 - Microstructures">213</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>:

               <div class="paragraph-element">For another kind of metal-active phosphides, which experience a reversible conversion reaction mechanism, the process can be expressed in the following equation<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0214" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0214_R_d33609751e4741" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 214 - Energy Storage Mater.">214</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0215" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0215_R_d33609751e4741" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 215 - Energy Storage Mater.">215</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>:

                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0004"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/6be15bab-29d5-456e-a61c-8ac22bd7720f/cnl2171-math-0004.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0004" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0004.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>MP</mtext>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mrow>
                                       <mo>(</mo>

                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi>

                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi>

                                    </mrow>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
