                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mrow>
                                       <mo>(</mo>
                                       <mn>3</mn>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi>
                                       <mo>)</mo>
                                    </mrow>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>↔</mo>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>xNa</mtext>
                                       <mn>3</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0004" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0004.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;MP&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mo&gt;(&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;y&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;)&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mo&gt;(&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;y&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;)&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;xNa&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;P&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;y&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;M&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(4)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <div class="paragraph-element">When non-P element (M) in the phosphides can react with sodium, there are also two main kinds of reactions involved. For some metal phosphides, the metal and P atoms can reform MPs during desodiation as shown in Equation (<a class="equationLink scrollableLink" href="#cnl2171-disp-0005" title="Link to equation">5</a>),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0202" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0202_R_d33609751e4806" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 202 - J. Mater. Chem. A">202</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0216" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0216_R_d33609751e4806" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 216 - Adv. Energy Mater.">216</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0217" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0217_R_d33609751e4806" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 217 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">217</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> while the other one cannot, which only generates pure P after the desodiation reaction as given in Equations (<a class="equationLink scrollableLink" href="#cnl2171-disp-0006" title="Link to equation">6</a>) and (<a class="equationLink scrollableLink" href="#cnl2171-disp-0007" title="Link to equation">7</a>)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0218" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0218_R_d33609751e4818" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 218 - Chem. Commun.">218</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0220" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0220_R_d33609751e4818" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 220 - J. Power Sources">220</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>:

                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0005"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/36ec2ca9-7fdb-41ce-971b-e7f2be871f82/cnl2171-math-0005.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0005" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0005.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>MP</mtext>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>3</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>xNa</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>3</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>xe</mtext>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>↔</mo>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>xNa</mtext>
                                       <mn>3</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi>
                                    <mo>,</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0005" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0005.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;MP&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;xNa&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;xe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;xNa&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;P&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;M&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;,&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(5)</span></div>
                  
                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0006"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/22c6a690-be01-4871-a3db-b46df720dd81/cnl2171-math-0006.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0006" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0006.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>MP</mtext>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>3</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>xNa</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>+</mo>

                                       <mtext>xe</mtext>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>→</mo>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>xNa</mtext>
                                       <mn>3</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi>
                                    <mo>,</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0006" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0006.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;MP&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;xNa&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;xe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02192}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;xNa&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;P&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;M&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;,&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(6)</span></div>
                  
                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0007"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/298cdf0a-f3bf-4a9f-8acb-4a1802ec09f9/cnl2171-math-0007.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0007" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0007.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mn>3</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi>
                                    <mo>↔</mo>
                                    <mn>3</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>

                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>3</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0007" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0007.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;P&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;P&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(7)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>Compared with those of pure phosphorus, the reaction mechanisms of phosphides are more complicated due to the presence of metal elements. However, when the chemical bonds between P and metal atoms are broken, metal nanoparticles may be formed, which can perform as a conductive medium to improve the ion diffusion kinetics and buffer the stress from volume expansion to enhance its electrochemical properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0144" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0144_R_d33609751e4922" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 144 - Nano Res.">144</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Similarly, phosphides also suffer large volume variation and poor ion transfer kinetics, severely limiting the cyclic span as SIB anodes.</p>
               
               <div class="article-table-content" id="cnl2171-tbl-0004">
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  <header class="article-table-caption"><span class="table-caption__label">Table  4.

                           <tr>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">N, P-doped carbon-confined Cu<sub>3</sub>P nanoparticles</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">0.22–0.89</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">332 (50 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">76.0</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">86.8% (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 100 cycles)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0216" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0216_R_d33609751e5439" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 216 - Adv. Energy Mater.">216</a></span>]</td>
                              </tr>
                           
                           <tr>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">FeP@N-doped CNSs</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">-</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">305 (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">44.2</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">90.7% (500 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 4500 cycles)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0221" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0221_R_d33609751e5470" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 221 - Chem. Eng. J.">221</a></span>]</td>

                  </div>
                  
                  <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
               </div>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0009"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/af8103c6-664c-4fab-a8b5-42a6067df390/cnl2171-fig-0009-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/af8103c6-664c-4fab-a8b5-42a6067df390/cnl2171-fig-0009-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/13fa04e6-f8da-4ff1-b6ba-77cc65138cfa/cnl2171-fig-0009-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/af8103c6-664c-4fab-a8b5-42a6067df390/cnl2171-fig-0009-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 9<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0009&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Schematic illustration of the formation of FeP@PNC composite. (b) Schematic illustrations for the sodiation/desodiation processes of FeP@PNC anode. (c) Top and side views of sodium adsorption on FeP/graphene with carbon vacancy structures. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2022, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0221" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0221_R_d33609751e5664" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 221 - Chem. Eng. J.">221</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (d) Schematic diagram for the synthesis of FeP NSs@rGO and expanded FeP NSs@rGO nanocomposites. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2022, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0222" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0222_R_d33609751e5669" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 222 - Nanoscale">222</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (e) Schematic representation of growth mechanism and corresponding SEM images at different synthesis stages of the Cu<sub>3</sub>P@C5. (f) Discharge capacities at 1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> of Cu<sub>3</sub>P, C<sup>P</sup>, Cu<sub>3</sub>P/C, and Cu<sub>3</sub>P@C composites. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, The Royal Society of Chemistry.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0224" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0224_R_d33609751e5689" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 224 - J. Mater. Chem. A">224</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (g) The synthesis process of the Ni<sub>2</sub>P@C-N⊂CF. (h) Schematic diagram of the sodiation-desodiation processes of Ni<sub>2</sub>P@C-N⊂CF. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0225" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0225_R_d33609751e5698" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 225 - Electrochim. Acta">225</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               
               <p>Rational structural and compositional designs have been proposed to address the above issues. Recent progress on a rang of metal phosphides is summarized in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0004">4</a>. Constructing metal phosphides/carbon heterostructures is the most cost-effective and efficient approach now. Jiang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0221" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0221_R_d33609751e5709" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 221 - Chem. Eng. J.">221</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> explored a facile and eco-friendly method to evenly embed FeP nanoparticles into 3D carbon frameworks with N, P co-doping (FeP@PNC) through a recrystallization self-assembly process under modest temperature (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0009">9a</a>). Engross architecture with 3D carbon frameworks could not only offer extra space for accommodating the volume expansion during repeated cycling but also provide conductive highways and rapid diffusion channels for electrons/ions. Meanwhile, in situ introduction of FeP nanoparticles into the vacancy carbon by N, P-co-doped can dramatically reduce the risk of fracture after deep cycling and create more defects in the interface for sodium storage. Such an engross architecture and interfacial interaction between FeP and carbon provided the FeP@PNC hybrids with large free space for accommodating the volume expansion during the repeated Na ion insertion and extraction processes (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0009">9b</a>), as well as provided conductive mediums and rapid mass and charge diffusion channels, ensuring the stable structure and electrical integrity to ensure the boosted reaction kinetics. At the same time, the introduction of ultrafine FeP nanoparticles and N, P foreign atoms into carbon prevented the aggregation of nanoscale FeP particles and reduced the possibility of breakdown. More importantly, DFT calculations demonstrated that the carbon with doping was more active to the Na ions (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0009">9c</a>), corresponding to superior reversible capability (340.1 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>). Park et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0222" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0222_R_d33609751e5730" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 222 - Nanoscale">222</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed a sandwich-like heterostructure of iron-phosphide nanosheets and rGO with polystyrene beads (PSBs) as a sacrificial template to expand the layers space (expanded FeP NSs@rGO), utilizing a charge-driven self-assembly strategy and a subsequent phosphorization/annealing process, as offered in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0009">9d</a>. Given the synergistic effect of FeP, rGO, and the porous structure, such a design not only offered ample space to ameliorate ion accessibility and structural integrity but also enhanced the resistance of oxidation from air and moisture exposure. Moreover, benefiting from the reduction reaction of oxidized iron-phosphides (Fe-PO<sub>x</sub>) by PSBs, which inevitably produced oxidized metal-phosphide (M-PO<sub>x</sub>) during the synthesis process and was directly related to the decrease in capacity, FeP NSs@rGO anode maintained a high ratio of FeP/Fe-PO<sub>x</sub>, resulting in a superior reversible specific capacity (916.1 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>). Wu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0223" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0223_R_d33609751e5752" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 223 - J. Mater. Sci.">223</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> elaborated a pomegranate-like mesoporous structure, in which the Fe<sub>2</sub>P nanoparticles were coated with a double carbon shell (Fe<sub>2</sub>P@C@NC). It was clear that nanosized Fe<sub>2</sub>P shortened the diffusion length, and the unique double-layer carbon-coated structure effectively tuned the size of Fe<sub>2</sub>P nanoparticles (inner carbon shell) to buffer the volume expansion (outer carbon layer), presenting a high specific capacity of 408 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, excellent rate performance, and stable capacity retention. Copper phosphides are typical metal-active phosphides, and thus the reaction mechanism follows Equation (<a class="equationLink scrollableLink" href="#cnl2171-disp-0005" title="Link to equation">5</a>). Zhu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0224" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0224_R_d33609751e5776" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 224 - J. Mater. Chem. A">224</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> fabricated Cu<sub>3</sub>P@C heterostructured nanosheet composite as an SIB anode material by a simple route combined epitaxial phosphidation growth/carbon deposition processes. Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0009">9e</a> provides a schematic overview indicating the key Stages of Cu<sub>3</sub>P@C5 growth during the pyrolysis reaction. The thin Cu<sub>3</sub>P nanosheet core-carbon shell morphology with flower-like 3D superstructure was the key to excellent electrochemical performance. Overall, benefiting from the structural features compared with the reference materials, the Cu<sub>3</sub>P@C5 anode exhibited a specific capacity of 156 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 1000 cycles at 1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0009">9f</a>).</p>
               
               <p>Similarly, nickel phosphides follow the sodium storage mechanism similar to that of copper phosphides, which has raised the attention of researchers. In this regard, Li et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0225" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0225_R_d33609751e5805" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 225 - Electrochim. Acta">225</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> first designed and embedded Ni<sub>2</sub>P polyhedron particles into carbon fibers (Ni<sub>2</sub>P@C-N⊂CF) via immersing and subsequent calcination-phosphatization approaches (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0009">9g</a>). In the prepared microporous structure, Ni<sub>2</sub>P nanoparticles were uniformly distributed in carbon fibers, shortening the Na ion diffusion path. The microporous graphitic carbon shell and carbon fibers feature contain conductive channels and adequate free space, which aided in decreasing volume variation and facilitating electrolyte permeation, as denoted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0009">9h</a>. This obviously demonstrated that Ni<sub>2</sub>P@CeN still maintained a perfect polyhedron shape during repeated ion insertion/extraction. As a flexible self-supporting anode material for SIBs, it delivered a super-stable specific capacity of 196.8 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 1000 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> over 1000 cycles with a capacity dropping of 0.04% cycle<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, indicating extraordinary cycling durability and superiorly high-rate performance. Zheng&nbsp;et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0226" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0226_R_d33609751e5835" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 226 - J. Mater. Sci.">226</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> immobilized Ni<sub>5</sub>P<sub>4</sub> nanospheres into the rGO to fabricate 3D hierarchical nanostructures (Ni<sub>5</sub>P<sub>4</sub>@rGO) through solvothermal reaction and further phosphidation by using hypophosphate as the precursors. The Ni<sub>5</sub>P<sub>4</sub>@rGO anode presents excellent electrochemical performance of a worthwhile reversible specific capacity of 304 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 200 cycles at 0.2 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. The conductive rGO with the even distribution of nanosized Ni<sub>5</sub>P<sub>4</sub> was beneficial for enhancing capacity and cycling performance by inhibiting aggregation and collapse of Ni<sub>5</sub>P<sub>4</sub> active material. Although the electrochemical performance of metal phosphides has been gradually enhanced in the past few years, they still suffer insufficient capacity in contrast to other anode materials, because partial metal phosphides in the synthesis process are vulnerable to oxidation and hydrolysis, generating toxic phosphine (PH<sub>3</sub>). Furthermore, a large number of studies have been conducted to combine phosphides with carbon currently, which could only contribute to limited performance enhancement. To this end, bimetal phosphides need to be designed to guarantee richer active sites and superior electrical conductivity.</p>
               </section>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0120">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="cnl2171-sec-0120-title">3.3 Iron-based materials</h3>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0130">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0130-title">3.3.1 Iron oxides</h4>
               
               <div class="paragraph-element">Iron oxides are one of the most common rock-forming compounds in the earth, which is widely investigated for the energy storage industry currently. Because iron is the typical metal element with variable valences from −2 to +7, there are many types of iron oxides in iron ore such as wustite (FeO), magnetite (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>), hematite (α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>), and maghemite (γ-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0227" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0227_R_d33609751e5899" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 227 - J. Mater. Chem. A">227</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> As SIB anodes, iron-oxides feature low cost and high theoretical specific capacity based on the conversion mechanism in the following equations.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0228" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0228_R_d33609751e5904" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 228 - Adv. Energy Mater.">228</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0231" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0231_R_d33609751e5904" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 231 - Chem. Eng. J.">231</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>
                  
                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0008"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/b8197813-f12c-4bb8-85a9-c67afb68fe47/cnl2171-math-0008.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0008" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0008.png">

                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0009" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0009.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Fe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;O&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;6&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Fe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;O&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;,&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(9)</span></div>
                  
                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0010"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/a00708fd-e125-44ea-b406-32f00967c75f/cnl2171-math-0010.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0010" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0010.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Fe</mtext>
                                       <mn>3</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi>
                                       <mn>4</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>8</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>↔</mo>
                                    <mn>3</mn>
                                    <mtext>Fe</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>4</mn>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0010" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0010.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Fe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;O&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mn&gt;4&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;8&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Fe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;4&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;O&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(10)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>Unfortunately, they usually suffer two fatal shortcomings of large volume changes during Na ion insertion/extraction and sluggish ion diffusion kinetics, resulting in poor cycling performance and unsatisfactory capacity, respectively.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0232" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0232_R_d33609751e6002" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 232 - Adv. Mater.">232</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0233" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0233_R_d33609751e6002" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 233 - Small">233</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Futhermore, iron oxides are electrochemically inactive in SIBs. Therefore, the particles of these iron oxides or iron-based oxides should be as small as ∼5–20 nm, otherwise severe electrochemical polarization and incomplete conversion reactions may occur.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0234" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0234_R_d33609751e6007" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 234 - Energy Storage Mater.">234</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, there are two common strategies to improve their electrochemical performance, one is tailoring the nanostructure of iron oxides<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0032" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0032_R_d33609751e6012" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 32 - J. Alloys Compd.">32</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0235" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0235_R_d33609751e6012" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 235 - J. Alloys Compd.">235</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0236" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0236_R_d33609751e6012" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 236 - J. Colloid Interface Sci.">236</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and the other is combining iron oxides with a carbon conductive matrix.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0032" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0032_R_d33609751e6018" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 32 - J. Alloys Compd.">32</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0237" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0237_R_d33609751e6018" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 237 - Composites, Part B">237</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The detailed electrochemical performances of various iron oxides are summarized in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0005">5</a>.</p>
               
               <div class="article-table-content" id="cnl2171-tbl-0005">
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  <header class="article-table-caption"><span class="table-caption__label">Table  5.
                    </span>Electrochemical performance of iron-based anodes for SIBs.</header>
                  
                  
                  
                  <div class="article-table-content-wrapper" tabindex="0">
                     <table class="table article-section__table">

                           <tr>
                              
                              <th class="bottom-bordered-cell right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Type</th>
                              
                              <th class="bottom-bordered-cell left-aligned">Anode material</th>
                              
                              <th class="bottom-bordered-cell left-aligned">Redox potential (V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>)</th>
                              
                              <th class="bottom-bordered-cell left-aligned">Practical capacity (mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> or mAh cm<sup>−</sup><sup>2</sup>)</th>
                              
                              <th class="bottom-bordered-cell left-aligned">ICE (%)</th>
                              
                              <th class="bottom-bordered-cell left-aligned">Cycling stability</th>
                              
                              <th class="bottom-bordered-cell left-aligned">References</th>
                              </tr>

                              <td class="left-aligned">73.4</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">-</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0039" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0039_R_d33609751e6843" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 39 - Nano-Micro Lett.">39</a></span>]</td>
                              </tr>
                           
                           <tr>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">Fe<sub>1-x</sub>S@PCNWs/rGO</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">0.20–1.83</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">600 (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">66.2</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">92.2% (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 100 cycles)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0255" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0255_R_d33609751e6876" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 255 - Adv. Energy Mater.">255</a></span>]</td>
                              </tr>
                           
                           <tr>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">Fe<sub>1-x</sub>S/N-CNFs</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">0.30–1.40</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">549 (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">63.9</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">79.1% (1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 800 cycles)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0256" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0256_R_d33609751e6910" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 256 - J. Alloys Compd.">256</a></span>]</td>
                              </tr>
                           </tbody>
                        </table>
                  </div>
                  
                  <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
               </div>
               <div class="paragraph-element">As the previous study reported, nanosized structures have many vital favorable factors for the SIB anode, such as larger active surface area and shorter diffusion pathway, which is suitable for the fabrication of iron oxides. This means a larger diffusion rate based on Equation (<a class="equationLink scrollableLink" href="#cnl2171-disp-0011" title="Link to equation">11</a>),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0257" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0257_R_d33609751e6923" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 257 - Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.">257</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> where t, L, and D represent the time corresponding to diffusion, the diffusion distance, and the diffusion constant, respectively.

                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0011"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/79b2191d-0466-40d5-b98b-eaca6dda72bc/cnl2171-math-0011.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0011" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0011.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi>
                                    <mo>=</mo>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>/</mo>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0011" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0011.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;t&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0003D}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;L&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;/&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;D&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(11)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>Combining with carbon is the most common strategy for enhancing the electrochemical performance of iron-based anodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0238" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0238_R_d33609751e6950" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 238 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">238</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0258" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0258_R_d33609751e6950" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 258 - Electrochim. Acta">258</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0259" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0259_R_d33609751e6950" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 259 - J. Power Sources">259</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> With carbon layer wrapping or carbon serving as a substrate, it simultaneously functions as a flexible buffering matrix to alleviate the stress as well as a conductive medium to facilitate charge transportation. Li and colleagues designed such a novel architecture, of which Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles were dispersed in nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon nanospheres (MFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@N-HCNs).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0239" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0239_R_d33609751e6964" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 239 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">239</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0010">10a</a> illustrates the synthetic procedure of MFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@N-HCNs, in which the Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> was movable through the interconnected pores. Benefiting from the synergistic effect, the MFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@N-HCNs anode exhibited excellent electrochemical performance with an impressively high reversible specific capacity of 417 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 100 cycles at 0.1 Ag<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> and 364 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 4500 cycles at 2 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Specifically, the pores with moveable Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> core (∼5 nm) served as buffer structures to relieve the huge volume effect and conductive network to accelerate the transport of Na ions (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0010">10b</a>). Song et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0240" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0240_R_d33609751e7006" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 240 - J. Alloys Compd.">240</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used self-polymerization of dopamine derivative to synthesize the Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles wrapped by adjustable N-doped graphitic carbon layer (Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NGC). The introduction of NGC improved the electrical conductivity and sodium-ion diffusion kinetics by providing porous structures, affording an excellent cycling performance with a reversible discharge specific capacity of 502.9 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.1 C after 150 cycles. Numerous of research have been conducted based on crystalline Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, and according to recent studies, materials with amorphous structures exhibit unique characteristics compared with crystalline counterparts, such as better mechanical stability<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0260" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0260_R_d33609751e7028" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 260 - J. Phys. Chem. Lett.">260</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and more effective ion diffusion.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0261" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0261_R_d33609751e7033" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 261 - Nano Energy">261</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0262" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0262_R_d33609751e7033" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 262 - Energy Environ. Sci.">262</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Shi et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0241" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0241_R_d33609751e7038" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 241 - Chem. Eng. J.">241</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> fabricated a porous amorphous Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/nitrogen-doped carbon composite (α-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/pBC-N) as an advanced anode for SIBs by in-situ growing amorphous Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> on the 3D interconnected nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers, as illuminated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0010">10c</a>. Improved reaction kinetics and better reversibility could be simultaneously realized by the amorphous structure of Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, leading to low Na<sup>+</sup> insertion energy (E<sub>ins</sub>), and the unique network structure with high content of nitrogen heteroatoms (10 at%), as revealed in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0010">10d</a>. Overall, it was uncovered that a porous 3D carbon framework, doping of N atoms, and amorphous structure buffered the anode volume expansion to alleviate the internal stress and provided abundant active sites to promote electron/ion transportation rate. Zhao et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0242" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0242_R_d33609751e7072" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 242 - Nano Energy">242</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> immobilized highly crystallized Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> nanoparticles into the hollow nitrogen-doped carbon nanospheres (HCM-Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@void@N-C) via successive sol-gel coating methods combined with confinement calcination strategy, as listed in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0010">10e</a>. Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> in the HCM-Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@void@N-C anode showed a highly crystallized structure, inducing high specific surface area and fewer citrate groups to increase the electrical conductivity of the nanocomposites. In addition, it is pointed out in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0010">10f</a> that the yolk-shell structured HCM Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@void@N-C nanospheres with large void space not only accommodated the volume expansion during repeated Na ion insertion/extraction to form a stable SEI film but also acted as a wall to prevent the electrolyte from wetting the interior. Huang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0243" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0243_R_d33609751e7105" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 243 - J. Alloys Compd.">243</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed a sealed structure in which hollow Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> nanospheres were encapsulated in intertwined N-doped carbon nanofibers (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>-CNFs) via electrospinning and high-temperature calcination, as indicated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0010">10g</a>. Such an encapsulated structure enables it high and robust contact area with effective electron/ion transportation and a remarkable cycling performance of 358.1 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.5 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 200 cycles, as suggested in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0010">10h</a>. In addition to SIBs, it also exhibited rapid charge transport and ion diffusion, consistent with its application in SIBs (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0011">10i</a>). With its unique advantages, it was concluded that iron oxides are promising anode candidates for SIBs. Designing nanostructures is a common approach, but the rapid increase of the particle surface area as the size decreases brings certain side effects of promoting the possibility of reaction with the electrolyte. This issue, if without balanced, would substantially sacrifice the reversible specific capacities and reduce the Coulombic efficiencies based on iron oxide anodes.</p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0010"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/45cf8157-2123-4249-86da-2bfa49f7340b/cnl2171-fig-0010-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/45cf8157-2123-4249-86da-2bfa49f7340b/cnl2171-fig-0010-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/f934a36e-a126-4d10-b02e-4a331a06157a/cnl2171-fig-0010-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/45cf8157-2123-4249-86da-2bfa49f7340b/cnl2171-fig-0010-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">

                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Illustration for the synthetic procedure of MFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@N-HCNs. (b) Schematic diagram of the probable structural evolution of MFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@N-HCNs after several cycles. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2021, American Chemical Society.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0239" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0239_R_d33609751e7163" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 239 - ACS Appl. (d) DFT calculations about the optimized geometry structures of crystalline Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, Na ion-inserted crystalline Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, amorphous Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>, and Na ion-inserted amorphous Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> models. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0241" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0241_R_d33609751e7191" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 241 - Chem. Eng. J.">241</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (e) Schematic illustration for the synthesis of the yolk-shell structured Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>/N-doped carbon nanospheres with highly crystallized mesoporous Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> cores. Alloys Compd.">243</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               </section>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0140">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0140-title">3.3.2 Iron sulfides</h4>
               
               <p>Iron sulfides such as FeS, FeS<sub>2</sub>, Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub>, and Fe<sub>1-x</sub>S, were demonstrated as potential SIB anodes from the 1980s period, when FeS<sub>2</sub> was initially applied in the energy storage field. In contrast to iron oxides, they normally present more narrow energy gaps, which means higher electrical conductivity and weaker chemical bonds between Fe and S to pose better reversibility during sodium storage reactions. Nevertheless, up to now, only FeS<sub>2</sub> anode has been successfully used for commercial LIB electrodes,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0231" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0231_R_d33609751e7258" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 231 - Chem. Eng. J.">231</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0234" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0234_R_d33609751e7258" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 234 - Energy Storage Mater.">234</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> which is limited by low electron/ion transportation rate, large volume changes according to the conversion mechanism, and sluggish kinetics.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0263" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0263_R_d33609751e7263" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 263 - Nanoscale">263</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0265" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0265_R_d33609751e7263" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 265 - Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.">265</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Although iron sulfides contain Fe and S with different atomic ratios, they show similar crystal structures. Specifically, six S ions form an octahedron with a Fe ion in the center, and each octahedron is connected by a shared S ion.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0266" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0266_R_d33609751e7269" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 266 - Small">266</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0268" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0268_R_d33609751e7269" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 268 - J. Power Sources">268</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> With the intrinsic merits and shortcomings, great works were carried out to promote their application in practice, as summarized in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0005">5</a>.</p>
               
               <div class="paragraph-element">FeS has gained a wave of attention from researchers because of its high theoretical specific capacity (610 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>), natural abundance, and low cost, which are of great business value.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0244" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0244_R_d33609751e7283" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 244 - Adv. Mater.">244</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0269" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0269_R_d33609751e7283" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 269 - Nat. Commun.">269</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0271" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0271_R_d33609751e7283" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 271 - Small">271</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> To further exert the effect of FeS, it is necessary to understand its sodium storage mechanism, and the reaction can be expressed as follows<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0272" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0272_R_d33609751e7288" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 272 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">272</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0274" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0274_R_d33609751e7288" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 274 - Electrochim. Acta">274</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>:

                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0012"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/28461c0c-8aa8-40bf-a784-74818f8cc24e/cnl2171-math-0012.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0012" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0012.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <mtext>FeS</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>2</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>2</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>↔</mo>
                                    <mtext>Fe</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>2</mn>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0012" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0012.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;FeS&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Fe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;S&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(12)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>The conversion reaction is generally prone to render an excellent capacity, but the reversible capacity is unsatisfied when it is used as a SIB anode.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0275" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0275_R_d33609751e7328" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 275 - Int. J. Energy Res.">275</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Besides, scalable, nontoxic, and low-cost synthesis methods and raw materials are desirable from a practical perspective.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0244" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0244_R_d33609751e7333" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 244 - Adv. Mater.">244</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0269" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0269_R_d33609751e7333" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 269 - Nat. Commun.">269</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0271" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0271_R_d33609751e7333" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 271 - Small">271</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In 2019, Yang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0245" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0245_R_d33609751e7338" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 245 - J. Mater. Chem. A">245</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> explored a simple and environmentally friendly homogeneous carbothermal reduction strategy to prepare low-cost FeS@C anode, as depicted in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0011">11a</a>. It is believed that such a method was greatly suitable for large-scale production, and it was also beneficial for obtaining super electrochemical properties due to the partially involved conversion reaction, in which the carbon coating could largely relieve the volumetric variation to enable long-term cycling with high specific capacity (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0011">11b</a>). Lim et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0246" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0246_R_d33609751e7350" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 246 - Chem. Eng. J.">246</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> explored a one-step hydrothermal strategy under low temperatures to construct a carbon shell on the surfaces of mackinawite FeS (M-FeS), and this work provided a gentle solution to synthesize M-FeS with high electrical conductivity but low thermal stability. Wu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0276" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0276_R_d33609751e7356" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 276 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">276</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared 2D thin FeS nanosheets with carbon coating (FeS/C NS) transformed from pyrite FeS<sub>2</sub> with glucose by postannealing treatment at 500°C. The impressive electrochemical performance derived from superior electrical conductivity and interfacial sodium storage capability illustrates the importance of the phase transformation method to prepare FeS. Liu&nbsp;et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0247" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0247_R_d33609751e7363" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 247 - J. Alloys Compd.">247</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> utilized Fe-alginate as a biomass precursor to derive FeS nanoparticle (NP) and three-dimensional (3D) carbon nanofiber aerogels (CNA) composites (FeS/CNA). As an anode for SIBs, the FeS/CNA anode showed outstanding specific capacity (473 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>) and excellent cycle stability (over 400 cycles at 2 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>), demonstrating it was an ideal material for practical production to reduce the cost and protect the environment.</p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0011"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/a510d2a4-10e3-4573-be6f-fd6113177565/cnl2171-fig-0011-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/a510d2a4-10e3-4573-be6f-fd6113177565/cnl2171-fig-0011-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/9d4b0c91-8b33-4fe5-8e60-70e0fe7365bd/cnl2171-fig-0011-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/a510d2a4-10e3-4573-be6f-fd6113177565/cnl2171-fig-0011-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 11<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0011&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Schematic diagram of the synthetic process of FeS@C. (b) Schematic illustration of the phase and structure evolution during the charge/discharge processes of the FeS@C anode with partial conversion reaction. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, American Chemical Society.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0245" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0245_R_d33609751e7398" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 245 - J. Mater. Chem. A">245</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (c) Schematic illustration of the fabrication process of Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub>/N-CNFs. (d) Scheme representation of the advantages of Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub>/N-CNFs as an anode in SIBs. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2021, Wiley.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0250" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0250_R_d33609751e7412" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 250 - Small">250</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (e) Synthesis illustration of the FeS<sub>2</sub> NT. (f) Intercalation-conversion mechanisms of the FeS<sub>2</sub> anodes during repeated electrochemical charge-discharge cycles. (g) Side view and Top view along the axis of an NT showing the nonuniform stress distribution of the tube-like FeS<sub>2</sub> upon sodiation process. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0277" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0277_R_d33609751e7424" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 277 - Nano Energy">277</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (h) Schematic illustration for the construction of the Fe<sub>1-x</sub>S@PCNWs/rGO hybrid paper. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, Wiley.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0255" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0255_R_d33609751e7431" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 255 - Adv. Energy Mater.">255</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               
               <div class="paragraph-element">Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> is a conductor with a band gap of zero, leading to good electrical conductivity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0234" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0234_R_d33609751e7444" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 234 - Energy Storage Mater.">234</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> also faces the same problems as other iron sulfides, including poor cycling performance, low ion transportation rate, and so on, which are caused by the conversion mechanism as expressed in the following equation<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0248" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0248_R_d33609751e7454" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 248 - J. Mater. Chem. A">248</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>:

                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0013"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/c8fd3426-d131-42f4-be32-0de227e74eed/cnl2171-math-0013.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0013" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0013.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Fe</mtext>
                                       <mn>7</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi>
                                       <mn>8</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>16</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>16</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>↔</mo>
                                    <mn>7</mn>
                                    <mtext>Fe</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>8</mn>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0013" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0013.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Fe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;7&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;S&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mn&gt;8&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;16&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;16&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;7&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Fe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;8&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;S&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(13)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>Generally, Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> could store 16Na ions, corresponding to a high theoretical specific capacity of about 660 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0249" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0249_R_d33609751e7507" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 249 - Nanoscale">249</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0278" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0278_R_d33609751e7507" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 278 - Electrochim. Acta">278</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, there are several main ideas to exert its effect as much as possible, including morphology and nanostructure design, as well as carbon decoration. Wang&nbsp;et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0250" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0250_R_d33609751e7513" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 250 - Small">250</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used metal-organic framework (MOF) containing Fe element as a precursor to fabricate a composite material, in which Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> nanoparticles were encapsulated in 3D interconnected N-doped carbon nanofibers (Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub>/NCNFs), as displayed in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0011">11c</a>. The extremely small nanoparticles with an average diameter of 17 nm effectively were fully utilized during repeated Na ion insertion/extraction and shortened the ion diffusion pathway. In addition, the unique 1D/3D architecture not only facilitated electron/ion transport but also prevented the self-agglomeration of Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0011">11d</a>). Therefore, the Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub>/N-CNFs anode showed outstanding long-term cycling stability (472.1 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 2000 cycles). Zhang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0251" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0251_R_d33609751e7548" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 251 - J. Energy Chem.">251</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed and synthesized Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> nanoparticles encapsulated in N-doped hollow carbon fibers (NHCFs/Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub>), and thanks to the robust structure, NHCFs/Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> greatly overcome the volume changes and agglomeration, showing high reversibility and electrical conductivity. Peng et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0252" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0252_R_d33609751e7567" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 252 - J. Alloys Compd.">252</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized graphitized carbon/Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> (CFGC/Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub>) composites via converting waste cotton fiber into intermediates and subsequently sulfurization, and they verified the role of partly graphitized carbon fiber and in situ conversion, providing a new way for transferring waste textiles into advanced anode materials for SIBs. Recently, Zhang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0253" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0253_R_d33609751e7581" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 253 - Adv. Energy Mater.">253</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> thoroughly studied the impact of Na-doping on the Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> via experimental results as well as theoretical analysis. The results revealed that Fe-S bond strength was weakened, while Fe vacancies were generated by sodium doping, accelerating the kinetics of sodiation/desodiation reactions. Simultaneously, sodium heteroatoms could induce the formation of stable SEI films, facilitating the deposition of sodium-containing components.</p>
               
               <div class="paragraph-element">FeS<sub>2</sub>, the only successful commercial iron sulfides for LIBs anode,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0270" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0270_R_d33609751e7595" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 270 - Energy Environ. Sci.">270</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> still faces some handicaps in the way of practical applications for SIBs. However, compared with other iron sulfides, FeS<sub>2</sub> shows an extremely high theoretical specific capacity of 894 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup><sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0279" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0279_R_d33609751e7605" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 279 - J. Mater. Chem. A">279</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> with a two-step sodium storage reaction pathways of intercalation step and conversion step, as expressed in the following equations<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0280" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0280_R_d33609751e7610" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 280 - J. Phys. Soc. Jpn.">280</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>:

                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0014"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/e1073810-d0de-4e15-8464-83809fe22ab2/cnl2171-math-0014.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0014" display="block" linebreak="nobreak" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0014.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>FeS</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>xNa</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>+</mo>

                                       <mtext>xe</mtext>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
