                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0014" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0014.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" linebreak="nobreak"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;FeS&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;xNa&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;xe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02192}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;FeS&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mo&gt;(&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0003C}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mo&gt;)&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;mo&gt;(&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;above&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mspace width="0.5em"/&gt;&lt;mn&gt;0.8&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;V&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;)&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mo&gt;,&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(14)</span></div>
                  
                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0015"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/d600e16f-6e46-4f01-8791-ed03d5259d1a/cnl2171-math-0015.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0015" display="block" linebreak="goodbreak" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0015.png">

                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0015" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0015.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" linebreak="goodbreak"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;FeS&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mo&gt;(&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;4&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;)&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mo&gt;(&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;4&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;x&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;)&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Fe&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;S&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;(&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;below&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mspace width="0.5em"/&gt;&lt;mn&gt;0.8&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;V&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;)&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(15)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>To overcome the handicap of FeS<sub>2</sub>, it is suggested that limiting potential windows to ensure the sodium storage process only takes place in the intercalation reaction, and reducing the volume changes seems a good strategy. However, it sacrifices most of the battery energy density, which does not aid in delivering a high theoretical capacity of FeS<sub>2</sub>. In another thought, Yao et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0277" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0277_R_d33609751e7721" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 277 - Nano Energy">277</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> applied morphological engineering in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0011">11e</a> to achieve polycrystalline FeS<sub>2</sub> nanotubes (NTs) coupled with in situ TEM images to corroborate the merits of such a design. As illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0011">11f</a>, the structure not only provided a straight ionic transport pathway to improve ionic diffusion kinetics in the intercalation reaction but also reduced large volume expansion and structural strain in the conversion reaction. Specifically, it was clear that in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0011">11g</a> the stress was prone to be nonuniform distribution upon the conversion step. From the top view, it however can be seen that the inner faces of the FeS<sub>2</sub> only suffered a small expansion stress, leading to superior cycling performance. Lu&nbsp;et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0254" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0254_R_d33609751e7740" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 254 - Chem. Eng. J.">254</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> encapsulated FeS<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles (5–12 nm) into N and S-doped (N, S-co-doped) carbon fibers (CFs) with adherent FeS<sub>2</sub> nanoflakes. It was noted that the carbon backbone with different nanostructures and elements doping not only improved the contact area with electrolyte to facilitate the ion diffusion but also acted as a buffer medium to prevent the structure from fracturing and maintain a long-time cyclic performance. Song et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0281" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0281_R_d33609751e7750" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 281 - Nano-Micro Lett.">281</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed a heterostructure based on Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub> and FeS<sub>2</sub>, which was encapsulated in N-doped CNT (Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub>/FeS<sub>2</sub>/NCNT). The unique nano-architecture and interface effect endowed the Fe<sub>7</sub>S<sub>8</sub>/FeS<sub>2</sub>/NCNT anode with substantial lattice defects, sufficient buffer space, and superior electrical conductivity.</p>
               
               <p>Fe<sup>2+</sup> has 24 electrons with the outer electrons structure of 3d<sup>5</sup>4s<sup>1</sup>, which means the Fe<sup>2+</sup> is not stable. Some Fe<sup>2+</sup> can be oxidized into Fe<sup>3+</sup> in the ambient, and subsequently, some Fe<sup>2+</sup> could lose to keep charge balance, forming Fe<sub>1-x</sub>S. Similar to other iron sulfides, its electrochemical performance is mainly improved by combining with carbonaceous materials and structural design. Liu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0255" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0255_R_d33609751e7795" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 255 - Adv. Energy Mater.">255</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> constructed a ternary film material composing Fe<sub>1-x</sub>S, porous carbon nanowires, and reduced graphene oxide (Fe<sub>1-x</sub>S@PCNWs/rGO), as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0011">11h</a>. As a flexible and foldable anode for SIBs, the paper anodes with areal mass loading of 0.9–11.2 mg cm<sup>−</sup><sup>2</sup> delivered high gravimetric (573–89 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>) and volumetric (429–107 mAh cm<sup>−</sup><sup>3</sup>) capacities after 100 consecutive cycles at 0.1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, and this benefits from the multidimensional hybrid feature, which can not only endow paper anodes with robust architecture and rapid electron/ion transport but also render the desirable pseudocapacitive contribution during the fast charge-discharge processes. Zhang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0256" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0256_R_d33609751e7821" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 256 - J. Alloys Compd.">256</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed and synthesized a composite, in which Fe<sub>1-x</sub>S nanoparticles were confined in N-doped carbon nanofibers (Fe<sub>1-x</sub>S/N-CNFs). The web-like structure can effectively buffer volume changes and prevent aggregation of active material to enhance the anode performance.</p>
               
               <p>Overall, although great efforts have been made focused on reducing volume expansion, enhancing electronic conductivity, and preventing the agglomeration of iron sulfides, some inspired results have been achieved via hardly a versatile, simple, and economical synthesis method to produce ideal anodes. Nowadays, researchers show a great interest in iron sulfide-based anodes, particularly suitable anodes for large-scale production that would be more attractive soon.</p>
               </section>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0150">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="cnl2171-sec-0150-title">3.4 Manganese-based materials</h3>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0160">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0160-title">3.4.1 Manganese oxides (MnO<sub>x</sub>)</h4>
               
               <p>As a promising class of transition metal oxides, MnO<sub>x</sub> including MnO,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0282" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0282_R_d33609751e7852" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 282 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">282</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0284" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0284_R_d33609751e7852" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 284 - Mater. Chem. Front.">284</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0285" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0285_R_d33609751e7862" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 285 - Chem. Eng. J.">285</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0286" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0286_R_d33609751e7862" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 286 - ACS Omega">286</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and MnO<sub>2</sub><sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0035" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0035_R_d33609751e7868" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 35 - RSC Adv.">35</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0287" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0287_R_d33609751e7868" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 287 - ChemNanoMat">287</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0289" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0289_R_d33609751e7868" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 289 - Energy Storage Mater.">289</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> gained great attention because of their high theoretical specific capacity, nature-abundance, environmentally safe, and cost-effective.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0234" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0234_R_d33609751e7873" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 234 - Energy Storage Mater.">234</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0275" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0275_R_d33609751e7873" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 275 - Int. J. Energy Res.">275</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0290" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0290_R_d33609751e7873" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 290 - Adv. Energy Mater.">290</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0291" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0291_R_d33609751e7873" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 291 - Nanoscale">291</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Nevertheless, the reversible capacities of MnO<sub>x</sub> as sodium ion active materials are much lower than their theoretical capacities and the cyclic life is greatly limited, which is caused by the low electron/ion transportation rate and the large volume changes during the repeated Na ion insertion/extraction.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0291" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0291_R_d33609751e7881" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 291 - Nanoscale">291</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0293" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0293_R_d33609751e7881" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 293 - Mater. Lett.">293</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> As a consequence, it is urgent to take measures such as nanostructure design, combining with various carbonaceous materials, and optimizing synthesis strategy to enhance the electrochemical performance and further lower the price from the large-scale production perspective. In Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0006">6</a>, we have listed the electrochemical performances of the manganese oxide anode materials for SIBs. It is widely accepted that nanostructure or downsized active material could shorten ion diffusion path and enlarge the specific surface area, greatly promoting the progress of electrochemical properties.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0294" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0294_R_d33609751e7890" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 294 - Small Methods">294</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Also, carbonaceous material with different nanoforms from various synthesis conditions and precursors can function as a buffer medium to alleviate the volume expansion and a conductive matrix to increase the electrical conductivity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0170" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0170_R_d33609751e7895" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 170 - Small">170</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0295" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0295_R_d33609751e7895" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 295 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">295</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <div class="article-table-content" id="cnl2171-tbl-0006">
                  
                  
                  
                  
                  <header class="article-table-caption"><span class="table-caption__label">Table  6.
                    </span>Electrochemical performance of different manganese-based anodes for SIBs.</header>

                           <tr>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">Hollow MnS/CNTs</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">0.20–2.00</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">649 (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">61.8</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">-</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0306" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0306_R_d33609751e8540" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 306 - Chin. Chem. Lett.">306</a></span>]</td>
                              </tr>
                           
                           <tr>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">MnS/N, S-doped CNTs</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">0.20–2.15</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">551 (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">72.1</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">94.3% (200 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 100 cycles)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0307" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0307_R_d33609751e8571" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 307 - Nanoscale">307</a></span>]</td>
                              </tr>
                           
                           <tr>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">MnS@N, S-doped carbon core/shell nanocubes</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">-</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">594 (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">-</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">79.6% (1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 3000 cycles)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0308" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0308_R_d33609751e8602" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 308 - Small">308</a></span>]</td>
                              </tr>
                           
                           <tr>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">MnS@CNWs/rGO</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">-</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">560 (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">50.4</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">87.7% (1 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 10000 cycles)</td>
                              
                              <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0309" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0309_R_d33609751e8633" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 309 - Nanoscale">309</a></span>]</td>
                              </tr>
                           </tbody>
                        </table>
                  </div>
                  
                  <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
               </div>
               <div class="paragraph-element">MnO possesses a theoretical specific capacity of 755.6 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> following a conversion reaction involved with an intercalation process as expressed in the following equation<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0282" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0282_R_d33609751e8646" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 282 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">282</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>:

                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0016"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/16b1de59-379a-4ebb-bad6-44641a80edc1/cnl2171-math-0016.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0016" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0016.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <mtext>MnO</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>2</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>2</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>→</mo>
                                    <mtext>Mn</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0016" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0016.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;MnO&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02192}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Mn&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;O&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(16)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>As we all know, both the quick fading capacity during cycling and the contribution of capacity are related to the conversion reaction.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0310" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0310_R_d33609751e8684" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 310 - Adv. Mater.">310</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0312" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0312_R_d33609751e8684" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 312 - Energy Environ. Sci.">312</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, the balance between the two is essential to improving electrical performance. Li et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0296" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0296_R_d33609751e8689" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 296 - J. Alloys Compd.">296</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> annealed Mn-based metal-organic framework (Mn-MOF) to obtain Mn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and then conducted a reduction to synthesize uniform MnO double-shell hollow nanospheres (h-MnO), as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0012">12a</a>. The ex-situ XRD results indicate that the insertion/extraction processes account for the majority of stored Na ions and further reduce the volume expansion. In addition, such a well-designed double shell morphology provided good structural stability to the anode, granting a greatly enhanced cycle life. Liu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0297" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0297_R_d33609751e8702" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 297 - Ionics">297</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized N-doped straw sheaf-like porous MnO@C composite. The structure assembled by an amorphous N-doped carbon matrix containing MnO nanoparticles with a diameter of ~15 nm was evenly packed and provided adequate void space for buffering the volume changes. In another case, a Platanus-fruit-like structure was constructed by Sun et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0284" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0284_R_d33609751e8707" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 284 - Mater. Chem. Front.">284</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> in which MnO nanoparticles were combined with nitrogen-doped porous carbon (NPC), contributing to good cycling stability and an enhanced rate capability.</p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0012"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/059dfef2-0141-4ecf-8806-64e60eed0785/cnl2171-fig-0012-m.jpg"><picture>

                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 12<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0012&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Synthesis illustration of h-MnO. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2022, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0296" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0296_R_d33609751e8732" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 296 - J. Alloys Compd.">296</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (b) Schematic illustration of the in situ assembly process for MnO<sub>2</sub> nanosheets (NSs) on carbon nanofibers (CNFs). (c) Cycling performance of MnO<sub>2</sub> NSs@ CNFs-1% for SIBs. (d) Photograph of the MnO<sub>2</sub> NSs@CNFs film. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2022, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0298" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0298_R_d33609751e8744" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 298 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">298</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (e) Schematic illustration of the process of structural evolution from a MnV<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub> nanorod bundle to a Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> microflower. (f) SEM image of Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>-G. (g) Cycling performance at 0.2 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2019, American Chemical Society.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0299" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0299_R_d33609751e8765" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 299 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">299</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (h) Synthetic procedure illustration of the Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@NC. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2021, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0300" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0300_R_d33609751e8775" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 300 - Chem. Eng. J.">300</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               
               <div class="paragraph-element">It is evident that MnO<sub>2</sub> could theoretically deliver a specific capacity of 1233 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0288" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0288_R_d33609751e8789" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 288 - ChemElectroChem">288</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0313" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0313_R_d33609751e8789" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 313 - Adv. Mater.">313</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0314" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0314_R_d33609751e8789" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 314 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">314</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and the mechanism can be presented as follows:

                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0017"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/0f1d8e32-a15f-4ded-b240-bccd3dbac7be/cnl2171-math-0017.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0017" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0017.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <mtext>First</mtext>
                                    <mspace width="0.5em"></mspace>
                                    <mtext>discharge</mtext>
                                    <mspace width="0.5em"></mspace>
                                    <mtext>process</mtext>
                                    <mo>:</mo>
                                    <mspace width="0.5em"></mspace>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>MnO</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>2</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>2</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>→</mo>
                                    <mtext>MnO</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi>
                                    <mo>,</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0017" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0017.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;First&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mspace width="0.5em"/&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;discharge&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mspace width="0.5em"/&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;process&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;:&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mspace width="0.5em"/&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;MnO&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02192}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;MnO&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;O&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;,&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(17)</span></div>
                  
                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0018"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/8bf208e8-987d-4f1d-8995-531f56dcbaa2/cnl2171-math-0018.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0018" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0018.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <mtext>Subsequent</mtext>
                                    <mspace width="0.5em"></mspace>
                                    <mtext>cycles</mtext>
                                    <mo>:</mo>
                                    <mspace width="0.5em"></mspace>
                                    <mtext>MnO</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi>
                                    <mo>↔</mo>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>NaMnO</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0018" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0018.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Subsequent&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mspace width="0.5em"/&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;cycles&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;:&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mspace width="0.5em"/&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;MnO&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;O&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;NaMnO&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(18)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>MnO<sub>2</sub> exists in several crystalline structures, that is, <i>α</i>, <i>β</i>, and <i>γ</i> appears as 1D tubular structures, and <i>δ</i> features a 3D spinel structure.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0315" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0315_R_d33609751e8884" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 315 - J. Phys. Chem. C">315</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Zheng&nbsp;et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0298" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0298_R_d33609751e8889" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 298 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">298</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed a 1D/2D freestanding anode, in which MnO<sub>2</sub> nanosheets were synchronous in situ spray onto carbon nanofibers (1D/2D MnO<sub>2</sub> NSs@CNFs), as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0012">12b</a>. Given the synergic effect of the structure and composition, 1D/2D MnO<sub>2</sub> NSs@CNFs anode demonstrated good cycling stability and the specific capacity increased from 160.3 to 175.1 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> after 500 charge/discharge cycles at 0.50 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0012">12c</a>). In addition, because the conventional collector is too heavy and unbendable, its application in energy storage such as wearable devices is limited, and the additives in it could significantly decrease the long cycling performance of batteries.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0316" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0316_R_d33609751e8914" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 316 - Chin. Chem. Lett.">316</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, a film with good integrity and flexibility (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0012">12d</a>) was obtained and used as a free-standing anode without additives and a current collector, and the whole mass functions as an active material, which effectively overcomes the problems above. A hierarchical lamellar structure was constructed, in which combined MnO<sub>2</sub> nanoflakes were coupled with graphene nanosheets (MnO<sub>2</sub>@graphene). Due to the graphene wrapping, MnO<sub>2</sub> nanosheets were endowed with vast space for preventing the structure collapse and the capacity deterioration caused by volume changes during cycling, large ions to transport and store, as well as huge surface area for reactions.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0317" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0317_R_d33609751e8929" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 317 - ChemistrySelect">317</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> With the preferable performance, this work fully proved that the hierarchical micro-structure of the anode is proverbially important for battery performance.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0318" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0318_R_d33609751e8934" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 318 - J. Energy Storage">318</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <div class="paragraph-element">Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> was considered to be one of the promising anode materials for SIBs according to its high theoretical specific capacity of 937 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0319" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0319_R_d33609751e8948" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 319 - Chem. Soc. Rev.">319</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Nevertheless, Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> suffers the common problems with those of other manganese oxides, leading to an unsatisfactory electrochemical performance. To combat these challenges, deeply understanding the sodium storage mechanisms is beneficial. Yusoff et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0286" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0286_R_d33609751e8958" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 286 - ACS Omega">286</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> clusters composed of numerous tiny nanoparticles and investigated their electrochemical reactions with Na ions by adopting an ex-situ X-ray diffraction technique. The results indicate that the reversible conversion reaction can be expressed as follows:

                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0019"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/867d1e61-5754-4af5-813b-33d836703eba/cnl2171-math-0019.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0019" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0019.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Mn</mtext>
                                       <mn>3</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi>
                                       <mn>4</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>8</mn>
                                    <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>8</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>↔</mo>
                                    <mn>3</mn>
                                    <mtext>Mn</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>4</mn>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0019" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0019.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Mn&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;O&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mn&gt;4&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;8&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;8&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;3&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Mn&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;4&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;O&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(19)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>Besides, a hierarchical microstructure of microflowers with ultrathin Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> and graphene was successfully fabricated using Mn<sub>2</sub>V<sub>6</sub> as templates (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0012">12e,f</a>). Benefiting from the synergic effect of the ultrathin nanosheet-assembled hierarchical structure and graphene decoration, the Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>-G anode displayed high outstanding cycling performance of ∼200 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 0.2 A g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> over 200 cycles (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0012">12g</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0299" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0299_R_d33609751e9033" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 299 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">299</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Qin et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0300" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0300_R_d33609751e9038" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 300 - Chem. Eng. J.">300</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed a core-shell structure composed of Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> and N-doped carbon (Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@NC) by the thermal oxidation of the MnO@ NC in the air, as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0012">12h</a>. The treatment with a temperature of 280°C can lead to a high purification, allowing for the formation of the Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>@NC in a limited oxidation duration. As the anode of SIBs, it can deliver excellent stable reversible capacities of 249.5 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, excellent rate capacities, and cycling stabilities. Yusoff et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0301" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0301_R_d33609751e9066" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 301 - J. Mater. Sci.">301</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> deposited Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> nanoparticles on the 3D network of rGO nanosheets uniformly, and such an architecture provided abundant interconnected voids for the deposition of Mn<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub> nanoparticles to alleviate the volume changes during cycles, as well as for electrons and ions to achieve highly efficient transportation.</p>
               
               <p>Manganese oxides have gained a wave of attention over the past few years due to their inherent characteristics such as abundant reserves, low cost, and high theoretical specific capacity compared with those of other transition metal oxides. Nevertheless, there are several challenges impeding their application in practice, such as unsatisfactory reversible capacity, lack of common synthesis method, and low Coulombic efficiency. With the rapid development of science and technology, it is believed that these problems, however, will be overcome in the future.</p>
               </section>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="cnl2171-sec-0170">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="cnl2171-sec-0170-title">3.4.2 Manganese sulfides</h4>
               
               <div class="paragraph-element">Manganese-sulfides exhibit the same properties as manganese-oxides because O and S are located in the same group. MnS possesses a high theoretical specific capacity of 616 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup><sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0302" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0302_R_d33609751e9093" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 302 - Chem. Eur. J.">302</a>-<a href="#cnl2171-bib-0304" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0304_R_d33609751e9093" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 304 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">304</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and excellent physical properties such as thermal and mechanical stabilities.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0320" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0320_R_d33609751e9098" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 320 - Chin. Chem. Lett.">320</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Generally, MnS follows a one-step conversion reaction to form Na<sub>2</sub>S and Mn crystalline (Equation&nbsp;<a class="equationLink scrollableLink" href="#cnl2171-disp-0020" title="Link to equation">20</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0305" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0305_R_d33609751e9109" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 305 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">305</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>
                  
                  <div class="inline-equation" id="cnl2171-disp-0020"><span class="inline-equation__construct"><!--FIGURE--><span class="fallback__mathEquation" data-altimg="/cms/asset/99a26644-8a8c-4d4e-a668-c6135f4ff1f1/cnl2171-math-0020.png"></span><math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0020" display="block" location="graphic/cnl2171-math-0020.png">
                           <semantics>
                              <mrow>
                                 <mrow>
                                    <mtext>MnS</mtext>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>2</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mo>+</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mn>2</mn>
                                    <msup>
                                       <mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi>
                                       <mo>−</mo>
                                    </msup>
                                    <mo>↔</mo>
                                    <msub>
                                       <mtext>Na</mtext>
                                       <mn>2</mn>
                                    </msub>
                                    <mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi>
                                    <mo>+</mo>
                                    <mtext>Mn</mtext>
                                    <mo>.</mo>
                                 </mrow>
                              </mrow>
                              <annotation encoding="application/x-tex"> &lt;math altimg="urn:x-wiley:27693333:media:cnl2171:cnl2171-math-0020" display="block" wiley:location="equation/cnl2171-math-0020.png" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mrow&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;MnS&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;msup&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;e&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02212}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/msup&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x02194}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;msub&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Na&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mn&gt;2&lt;/mn&gt;&lt;/msub&gt;&lt;mi mathvariant="normal"&gt;S&lt;/mi&gt;&lt;mo&gt;\unicode{x0002B}&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;mtext&gt;Mn&lt;/mtext&gt;&lt;mo&gt;.&lt;/mo&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/mrow&gt;&lt;/math&gt;</annotation>
                           </semantics></math></span><span class="inline-equation__label">(20)</span></div>
               </div>
               
               <p>Given its inherent issues, such as low electrical conductivity, poor ion transportation rate, and drastic volume variation, MnS with various synthesis conditions and carbon decorations was considered a promising anode for SIBs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0310" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0310_R_d33609751e9147" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 310 - Adv. Mater.">310</a>, <a href="#cnl2171-bib-0321" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0321_R_d33609751e9147" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 321 - Mater. Today">321</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> We have summarized the electrochemical performances of the recently reported manganese sulfide anode materials for SIBs in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0006">6</a>. Zhang et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0306" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0306_R_d33609751e9155" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 306 - Chin. Chem. Lett.">306</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> designed MnS hollow microspheres composited with 3D CNTs weave via a facile one-step solvothermal method (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0013">13a</a>). The hollow structure and porous network contributed to an enhanced sodium storage performance by providing a preferable electrical conductivity, adequate space to accommodate the volume changes, and a large contact area between the active materials and electrolyte. It is acknowledged that heteroatom doping could effectively enhance sodium storage properties by providing more active sites and enhancing electrical conductivity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0322" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0322_R_d33609751e9164" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 322 - J. Mater. Chem. A">322</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Li et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0307" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0307_R_d33609751e9169" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 307 - Nanoscale">307</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> encapsulated MnS cream into hollow N, S-co-doped carbon rolls (MnS/NSCT). It was apparent in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0013">13b</a> that carbon with N, S co-doping, and MnS respectively acted as “wall” and “cavity” to form a 3D cross-linked tubular structure to promote reversible sodium storage, delivering a high specific capacity of 550.6 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> at 100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> and 319.8 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> even at 10000 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>. Zhu et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0308" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0308_R_d33609751e9191" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 308 - Small">308</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> utilized as-prepared MnCO<sub>3</sub> nanocubes with a side length of 70–80 nm as templates to synthesize N, S co-doped carbon-coated MnS nanocubes (MnS@NSC), which feature a cube-like core/shell structure and strong C-S-Mn bond interactions. As described in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0013">13c</a>, in contrast to the pristine MnS counterpart, the generated Mn with well-defended in MnS@NSC retained a uniform dispersion explaining a high reversibility of MnS@NSC anodes, and the carbon shell significantly limited the volume expansion of MnS during the sodiation process, contributing to an excellent specific capacity. Sun et al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0309" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0309_R_d33609751e9201" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 309 - Nanoscale">309</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> constructed a flexible paper anode by embedding MnS nanoparticles (NPs) into carbon nanowires/rGO (MnS@CNWs/rGO), as presented in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0013">13d</a>. The well-designed architecture not only alleviated the volumetric expansion of MnS but also enhanced the electrochemical conductivity and pseudocapacitive contribution of the anodes, resulting in superlong cyclic life and outstanding rate capability. Besides, since the rebar-like nanowires were evenly distributed between the rGO layers acting as the supporter, the paper anode can be greatly reinforced (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0013">13f</a>) and could maintain anode integrity under tough threats (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0013">13e</a>). Although numerous relative reports have been conducted, the electrochemical properties of manganese sulfides still cannot meet the demand of application. Furthermore, it is evident that polysulphide dissolution in liquid electrolytes of manganese sulfide anodes leads to the deterioration of life cycle and capacity as well as the reduction of reversible specific capacities due to insufficient use of active materials. Therefore, to better overcome manganese sulfide intrinsic defect, the complex and controversial sodium storage processes need to be urgently revealed, and more attention should be paid to the high dissolvability of polysulfide, which could accelerate the capacity degradation and hence decrease battery Coulombic efficiency.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0323" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0323_R_d33609751e9216" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 323 - J. Mater. Chem. A">323</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0013"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/84a113bb-2553-41ab-8414-5adbffc8dd45/cnl2171-fig-0013-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/84a113bb-2553-41ab-8414-5adbffc8dd45/cnl2171-fig-0013-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/55c15142-c745-495e-95ad-ac0ca38ad18c/cnl2171-fig-0013-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/84a113bb-2553-41ab-8414-5adbffc8dd45/cnl2171-fig-0013-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 13<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0013&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Schematic illustration of the synthesis process of hollow MnS/CNTs composite. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, Elsevier.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0306" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0306_R_d33609751e9240" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 306 - Chin. Chem. Lett.">306</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (b) Micro-structure evolution of MnS/NSCTs during the sodium storage process. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, The Royal Society of Chemistry.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0307" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0307_R_d33609751e9245" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 307 - Nanoscale">307</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (c) Schematics comparing the discharge/charge processes in MnS@NSC and pristine MnS. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, Wiley.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0308" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0308_R_d33609751e9250" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 308 - Small">308</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (d) Synthesis schematic illustration of MnS@CNWs/rGO paper. (e) Digital images and (f) cross-sectional SEM images showing the appearance, flexibility, and thickness of MnS@CNWs/rGO paper. Reproduced with permission: Copyright 2020, The Royal Society of Chemistry.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0309" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0309_R_d33609751e9256" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 309 - Nanoscale">309</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               </section>
            </section>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="cnl2171-sec-0180">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="cnl2171-sec-0180-title">4 SUMMARY AND OUTLOOK</h2>
         
         <p>Compared with LIBs, SIBs have shown prominent advantages such as the wide availability, accessibility of Na source, and low cost, which are regarded as the most promising alternative energy storage devices. From a practical production point of view, the development of low-cost and high-performance anode is necessary for SIBs, and it is thus significant to select appropriate materials to construct them. Nowadays, there has been a growing number of studies aiming at the practical application of SIB anodes. We have summarized four kinds of ideal materials used as SIB anodes, including carbonaceous, phosphorus/phosphides, iron-based, and manganese-based materials, and various synthesis methods with economical, simple, and controllable were also offered. Furthermore, the performance enhancement as well as a deeper analysis of sodium storage mechanisms were discussed.</p>
         
         <p>Although great progress has been achieved on these anode materials for SIBs, there are still a few obstacles hindering their large-scale application which can be seen in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#cnl2171-fig-0014">14</a>. Among these issues, low ICE is the most common issue of SIB anodes, which is a key factor for the improvement of battery energy density. Generally, the capacity loss is mainly caused by the formation of the SEI layer and the irreversible insertion during the discharge/charge processes. Given the high Coulombic efficiency of 90% that can be achieved with commercial graphite anodes for LIBs, it is necessary to prevent the formation of the SEI layer and facilitate the reversible decomposition of products. It is found that large volume changes of more than 100% are another concern issue, resulting in repaid capacity decay, structural pulverization, and poor cycle performance. Generally, the volume changes should be limited to 30%, and in this regard, many measures have been taken including combining with a matrix to buffer the stress and constructing porous structures to accommodate the volume expansion. In addition, due to the larger radius of Na ions, SIBs suffer relatively sluggish diffusion kinetics within a solid anode during cycling when compared with LIBs, resulting in inferior rate capacity and power density. In this respect, there are certain crucial approaches in the design of materials, development of theory, and updating of the system, which would be effective through continual investigation.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="cnl2171-fig-0014"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/4e803d97-ada9-4a3b-8611-b44444e667d7/cnl2171-fig-0014-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/4e803d97-ada9-4a3b-8611-b44444e667d7/cnl2171-fig-0014-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/b9e239eb-1d13-4340-81cd-a379e736e3b7/cnl2171-fig-0014-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/4e803d97-ada9-4a3b-8611-b44444e667d7/cnl2171-fig-0014-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 14<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=cnl2171-fig-0014&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Fcnl2.171" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic showing the conclusion and perspective of the low cost and high abundance of anode materials.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         
         <p>As for further research on SIB anodes, the following points need to be focused on. First, incorporating two or more materials is one of the hottest topics, such as surface modification and constructing heterostructures, because single-phase material generally cannot approach the theoretical performance under multiple conflicting factors. By taking advantage of different components, they can not only complement each other but also realize the outcomes of 1 + 1 &gt; 2. Second, to better satisfy the requirement of practical production, it is urgent to discover new synthesis methods, because most of the current strategies (for instance CVD, chemical co-precipitation, and electrospinning, etc.) feature redundant procedures, low yield, high energy consumption, long fabrication time, and financial costs. Third, most of the studies have focused on the half-cell, in which Na metal is used to provide the “Na ion sea,” but this model means that the ICE is not real owing to the neglect of a part of the irreversible Na loss composed of SEI film. Although the ICE of half-cells has reached more than 90%, this achievement drops remarkably when it is based on the full cell, bringing about low energy density and high cost. We have listed detailed metrics for most of the anode materials mentioned in relation to the full cell in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#cnl2171-tbl-0007">7</a>. It is necessary to study the specific characteristics of sodium-ion full cells (SIFCs), and they are the bridge between theory and application, which more accurately reflects the practical performance of materials and closely resembles real-world application scenarios. Considering the fact that the SIFCs constitute a complex system, their encompassing cathode, anode, electrolyte, separator, and other materials. The current research should be extended to study the compatibility between them instead of being solely limited to the performance of individual parts. Furthermore, with the advanced characterization techniques including in situ XRD, Raman, and DEMS, more and more reaction details can be clearly explained, particularly the determination of reaction pathways and the study of electrolyte/anode interfaces, thus further contributing to optimizing SIB performance. In summary, considering the low cost and excellent performance of carbonaceous, iron-based, manganese-based, and phosphorus-based materials, these materials could be employed as anode materials to promote the commercialization of SIBs in the future.</p>
         
         <div class="article-table-content" id="cnl2171-tbl-0007">
            
            
            
            
            <header class="article-table-caption"><span class="table-caption__label">Table  7.

                        <td class="left-aligned">89.7 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                        
                        <td class="left-aligned">-</td>
                        
                        <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0303" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0303_R_d33609751e10541" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 303 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">303</a></span>]</td>
                        </tr>
                     
                     <tr>
                        
                        <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">MnS@C nanowires</td>
                        
                        <td class="left-aligned">Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub></td>
                        
                        <td class="left-aligned">-</td>
                        
                        <td class="left-aligned">2.95–3.15</td>
                        
                        <td class="left-aligned">80.0 mAh g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup> (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>)</td>
                        
                        <td class="left-aligned">89.0% (100 mA g<sup>−</sup><sup>1</sup>, 180 cycles)</td>
                        
                        <td class="left-aligned">[<span><a href="#cnl2171-bib-0305" class="bibLink tab-link" id="cnl2171-bib-0305_R_d33609751e10585" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 305 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">305</a></span>]</td>
                        </tr>
                     </tbody>
                  </table>
            </div>
            
            
            
            <div class="article-section__table-footnotes">
               <ul>
                  <li id="cnl2171-tbl7-note-0001">Abbreviations: DEC, diethyl carbonate; DGM, diglyme; DMC, dimethyl carbonate; DME, dimethyl ether; EC, ethylene carbonate; EMC, ethyl methyl carbonate; FEC, fluoroethylene carbonate; PC, propylene carbonate.</li>
               </ul>
            </div>
            <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
         </div>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="cnl2171-sec-0190">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="cnl2171-sec-0190-title"> AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS</h2>
         
         <p>Yichuan Dou was responsible for conceptualization, investigation, manuscript writing, and drawing. Yiming Zhang, Ruifeng Li, Xiaoqian Liu, and Ya Zhou provided valuable advice and assistance. Lanling Zhao, Zidong Zhang, and Yao Liu offered critical guidance on the manuscript. Jiazhao Wang and Jun Wang proposed the overall framework of the review and provided professional guidance and revisions.</p>
         </section>
      <div class="article-section__content">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="cnl2171-sec-0200-title"> ACKNOWLEDGMENTS</h2>
         
         <p>This work was financially supported by the National Key Research and Development Program of China (2022YFB3505104, 2022YFB3706604), the Natural Science Foundation of Shandong Province (ZR2022JQ19), the National Natural Science Foundation of China (51971119, 52171141, 52272117), and the Young Scholars Program of Shandong University (2019WLJH21).</p>
         
         <ol></ol>
      </div>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="cnl2171-sec-0210">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="cnl2171-sec-0210-title"> CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT</h2>
         
         <p>The authors declare no conflict of interest.</p>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section article-section__biography">
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title" id="biographies">Biographies</h2>
         <div class="biographies">
            <ul class="rlist">
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/8520d546-55cb-4ca3-834f-05142849fc80/cnl2171-bio-0001-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/8520d546-55cb-4ca3-834f-05142849fc80/cnl2171-bio-0001-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/1b8824b3-6f84-406f-8b2d-7831a385d6c7/cnl2171-bio-0001-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/8520d546-55cb-4ca3-834f-05142849fc80/cnl2171-bio-0001-m.jpg" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Yichuan Dou</b> is pursuing his Master degree under the supervision of Associate Professor Jun Wang from the Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution and Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), Shandong University. His research interests focus on the construction of advanced anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/9c7c6700-f3a2-45c3-996d-cb74f5d3a402/cnl2171-bio-0002-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/9c7c6700-f3a2-45c3-996d-cb74f5d3a402/cnl2171-bio-0002-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/36348c75-9e4e-4585-96e6-aefefa84eee9/cnl2171-bio-0002-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/9c7c6700-f3a2-45c3-996d-cb74f5d3a402/cnl2171-bio-0002-m.jpg" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Jiazhao Wang</b> obtained her Bachelor degree in Chemistry from Harbin Normal University, China. She then earned her PhD degree from the University of Wollongong (UOW), Australia, and has accumulated over 20 years of experience at the Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials (ISEM) at UOW. Currently, she is a Professor at the Technology Innovation Institute for Carbon Neutralization and the College of Chemistry and Materials Engineering at Wenzhou University. Additionally, she holds an Honorary Professorship at ISEM, University of Wollongong. Her research focuses on electrochemical energy storage in batteries, including Li/Na-ion batteries, Li/Na-sulfur batteries, and metal-air batteries. In 2021, she was elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry. She also serves as an Associate Editor of the journal Energy Materials.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/70e404c1-7441-4fb3-bdcd-e186682783e2/cnl2171-bio-0003-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/70e404c1-7441-4fb3-bdcd-e186682783e2/cnl2171-bio-0003-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/b3d2d269-1af0-4526-9f1e-ac4d1cff3fed/cnl2171-bio-0003-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/70e404c1-7441-4fb3-bdcd-e186682783e2/cnl2171-bio-0003-m.jpg" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Jun Wang</b> received his PhD degree in Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials from University of Wollongong in 2016. He is currently an Associate Professor at the Key Laboratory for Liquid-Solid Structural Evolution and Processing of Materials (Ministry of Education), Shandong University. His recent scientific interests are devoted to novel nanomaterials for electrochemical catalysis and rechargeable batteries.</p></li>
            </ul>
         </div>
      </section>
